title: Diatom Ribbons
label: Pyroclastic Records
description: Aided by Nels Cline, Marc Ribot, and Esperanza Spalding, the New York pianist and her band mix lyrical song form, turntablism, and avant-garde strategies in unusually fluid fashion.

title: Deceiver
label: Captured Tracks
description: The shoegaze band’s third album is another portrait of addiction and recovery, but this time there’s no suggestion of a victory lap. The lyrics may wallow, but the music soars.

title: Look Up Sharp
label: Kallista
description: The Australian multi-instrumentalist and songwriter’s second album finds a home in the shadowy space between post-punk, trip-hop, and lo-fi folk.

title: The Third Ascension
label: Systems Neutralizers
description: The celebrated avant-garde composer’s final work is a shrine to ecstatic disorientation.

title: So Removed
label: City Slang
description: The Queens band Wives channel the bygone squalor of NYC’s Y2K rock renaissance.

title: uknowhatimsayin¿
label: Warp
description: On his fifth album, executive-produced by Q-Tip, Danny Brown ascends to a sort of hip-hop classicist nirvana and remains one of the most inventive and dimensional rappers working today.

title: Carnage Hall
label: Upset the Rhythm
description: Building atop a wobbly foundation of post-punk totems, the Glaswegian sextet make complicated songs sound fun.

title: Room for Squares
label: Sony
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the auspicious debut that sent a 23-year-old guitarist into the stratosphere.

title: The Unluccy Luccy Kid
label: EMPIRE
description: The Brooklyn drill artist follows up his two-year-old hit “No Suburban” with a grim and terse debut LP.

title: Moments
label: Unseen Worlds
description: The New York-based composer’s third album spotlights piano and vibraphone, as attuned to the notes struck as to the overtones produced and their natural decay.

title: Make Yourself at Home
label: Skeletal Lightning
description: The 20-year-old singer-songwriter’s clear vocals and candid lyrics feel at home in the Philadelphia DIY scene that raised her.

title: All Mirrors
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The breathtaking songs of Angel Olsen’s fifth album are fleshed out by a 12-piece string section and deliver grand gestures about romance, authenticity, and being simply at the mercy of how we feel.

title: Abundance Welcoming Ghosts
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Animated with a new intensity, the Cornwall band’s fifth album may be its most ingenious and immersive mix of folk and rock yet.

title: LφVE & EVφL
label: Third Man
description: After nearly breaking up and instead making their best album in years, the once-restless Japanese trio become something new again: self-satisfied.

title: Losing, Linda
label: Cascine
description: On her alluring and unnerving new album, the Melbourne singer-songwriter adopts a digital alter-ego to explore real-life human strife.

title: The Afterlife
label: Impulse!
description: The cosmic fusion group skewers the jazz-trio format as it’s typically understood, flipping the minimalist palette into an electrifying, apocalyptic sound.

title: Love From the Planet Gong: The Virgin Years 1973-75
label: UMC
description: A mammoth box set of Daevid Allen’s prog-rock project makes a virtue of its excesses, capturing the band’s monumental strangeness.

title: Herstory in the Making
label: M.A. Music
description: The New York rapper’s highly anticipated debut album is another big, long flex from one of the most skilled rappers to emerge in the last five years.

title: Terms of Surrender
label: Merge
description: Working without his longtime collaborator Scott Hirsch, M.C. Taylor enlists guests Jenny Lewis and Aaron Dessner as he explores the heaviest questions and realizes there are no answers.

title: I’M HIM
label: Bread Winners’ Association
description: The follow up to 2016's revelatory Islah offers another showcase for the Baton Rouge rapper's fully formed and gloriously weird personality.

title: In the Morse Code of Brake Lights
label: Collected Works
description: Though a sense of doom lurks at the heart of the venerable band’s eighth album, they remain determined to keep classic guitar-pop alive by slyly twisting and expanding the form.

title: KIRK
label: Interscope
description: The Charlotte, North Carolina rapper's debut finds him in his sweet spot—which is to say, demolition mode.

title: The Adornment of Time
label: Pi
description: A live recording from New York’s the Kitchen captures a rare kind of improv synergy between the versatile composer-percussionist and a pianist who rose to fame in Anthony Braxton’s quartet.

title: SOUND & FURY
label: Elektra
description: The fourth album from the country outlaw is another left-turn with synth-rock at its scuzziest, boogie-rock at its cheesiest, all held together by Simpson’s fearless songwriting.

title: Prison on a Hill
label: Tiny Engines
description: The Boston rockers’ third album wears its radicalism with confidence, and the untimely death of the band’s guitarist lends their late-capitalist protest unfortunate urgency.

title: Prison on a Hill
label: Tiny Engines
description: The Boston rockers’ third album wears its radicalism with confidence, and the untimely death of the band’s guitarist lends their late-capitalist protest unfortunate urgency.

title: Dreams Are Not Enough
label: Ghostly International
description: The electronic outfit’s exquisitely bleak new record, the first since bandmate Charlie Cooper passed away, often feels like the very stuff of music is being torn apart.

title: Reservoir 1: Preservation
label: Black Truffle
description: Assisted by the pianist Phillip Bush and her colleagues in the percussion ensemble Meridian, the American composer tests conventional notions of musical narrative.

title: Weeping Icon
label: Fire Talk
description: The Brooklyn band skewers our collective relationship with social media—as well as their own—in noisy punk thrashers that are clever, incisive, and frequently very funny.

title: Face to Phase
label: Don't Be Afraid
description: The Berlin producer is unafraid to throw a wrench into her steady grooves, and her latest disregards clubland’s status quo for more imaginative terrain.

title: Blue World
label: Impulse!
description: Long-lost soundtrack recordings by the saxophonist’s powerhouse quartet, made shortly after 1964’s Crescent sessions, capture the band at the peak of its cohesion.

title: Gold: Greatest Hits
label: Polygram
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit an essential greatest hits album, one that brought ABBA indefinite fame.

title: NINE
label: Columbia
description: The shiny, beat-heavy sound of nu-blink-182 works in starts and stops, but feels half as fun as the band used to be.

title: Swoon / From Langley Park to Memphis / Jordan: The Comeback / A Life of Surprises
label: Sony Legacy
description: Four new vinyl reissues offer a thrilling survey of Paddy McAloon’s idiosyncratic journey as a pop songwriter.

title: Confetti
label: Generation Now
description: The genial Louisville rapper doesn’t have much of an identity, but he has a natural, low-stakes charm.

title: Chastity Belt
label: Hardly Art
description: They’ve abandoned the crude wit of their debut, but the Seattle band’s fourth album still maintains the closeness of hanging out with friends in your living room.

title: Hey, I’m Just Like You
label: Sire
description: On their ninth album, the twins revisit their roots, re-recording demos they wrote as teenagers and polishing them into poignant synth-pop gems.

title: The Talkies
label: Rough Trade
description: On their first new album in four years, the Irish punk quartet channel the sensation of pure, visceral panic through screeching sensory assaults and scrap-metal clang.

title: Songs From the Bardo
label: Smithsonian Folkways
description: Paired with drones from strings and struck bowls, the multimedia artist’s vivid readings from The Tibetan Book of the Dead offer the possibility of solace in sound itself.

title: Dead Man’s Pop
label: Rhino
description: The new box set includes demos, a live show, and a fascinating, stripped-down remix of the band’s 1989 album Don’t Tell a Soul that reveals an alternate history of one of their most divisive records.

title: Hot Motion
label: ATO
description: The British psych-rockers’ third album boasts studied musicianship and strong arrangements—and very little else.

title: Princess Catgirl
label: Mad Love
description: The Norwegian producer invents a Vocaloid-inspired feline character and retreats from the spotlit pop of his last album, returning to the introspective hush of his earlier work.

title: Miami Memory
label: Secretly Canadian
description: On his third album, the smooth Australian rocker leaves behind the arch character studies and tries to craft something more personal and sincere.

title: Only the Blues
label: Rvng Intl.
description: The singer-songwriter’s pillowy guitar pop comforts on the surface but pulses with nightmarish visions beneath.

title: MISCREANT
label: Atlantic
description: The 22-year-old Instagram stuntman turned TikTok sensation has been minorly famous for only a few months, but he already sounds washed up.

title: Memory
label: Polyvinyl
description: On their first new album since 2011, Vivian Girls jump back into fried guitar, loose percussion, and fast and easy repetition, as if they’d simply woken up from an eight-year nap.

title: Entre Los Dos EP
label: Tender Loving Empire
description: Luz Elena Mendoza follows her full-length Mujeres with an EP of introspective folk songs that understand just how visceral introspection can be.

title: 12 Conversations With Thilo Heinzmann
label: Deutsche Grammophon
description: Based on the paintings of Thilo Heinzmann and recorded by Brussels-based Echo Collective, this is the late Icelandic composer’s first proper work for string quartet alone.

title: Why Me? Why Not.
label: Warner Bros.
description: The former Oasis frontman’s second solo album is pitched as a re-introduction, but forward motion—whether musical or personal—remains foreign to him.

title: Vol. 2
label: Peak Oil
description: The shadowy creators behind Topdown Dialectic make electronic music as ceaseless as it is cryptic.

title: Sunshine Kitty
label: Island
description: The Swedish pop star’s fourth album contains some of her most vulnerable writing inside her clubbiest record.

title: Heaven Surrounds You
label: Danger Collective
description: The beachy post-punk duo are at their most confident, with a sense of anguish that brings emotional depth to otherwise plain lyrics.

title: The Brighter the Light
label: DFA
description: A collection of the duo’s 12" singles from the past six years proves their dancefloor nous but lacks the playfully eclectic spirit of previous albums.

title: DSVII
label: Mute
description: Released 12 years after Digital Shades Vol. 1, M83’s new collection of instrumentals doubles as a playful tribute to classic video-game soundtracks.

title: Karaoke Angel
label: Partisan
description: Bridging the sepia warmth of Laurel Canyon with Appalachian folk, the Mountain Man singer’s solo debut revels in the magic of telling your own story.

title: A Blaze in the Northern Sky
label: Peaceville
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a tense, beautiful, lo-fi landmark from the second wave of black metal.

title: Of the Sun
label: Glitterbeat
description: Channeling a wary mixture of dread and hope, the Polish indie rockers tighten the slackness of previous records into a potent fusion of post-hardcore and shoegaze.

title: Spirit Counsel
label: Daydream Library Series
description: Even with its imposing length and deep roster of collaborators, the ecstatic new album from Thurston Moore is arguably the most accessible entry point into his boundless experimental canon.

title: The Return
label: Ninja Tune
description: On her breakout debut, the promising Melbourne rapper wrestles with big ideas about peace, family, and home.

title: Ghostface Killahs
label: Music Generation Corp.
description: After a string of muted releases, Ghost strains to recapture some of the old Wu fire.

title: Jaime
label: ATO
description: The exceptional solo debut from the Alabama Shakes singer-songwriter is a thrilling opus that pushes the boundaries of voice, sound, and soul to new extremes.

title: Home Made Satan
label: Dine Alone
description: The Ontario musician slings revolutionary sentiments and blood lust for authority over bittersweet alt-rock.

title: Means to Me
label: Double Double Whammy
description: Leslie Bear’s second album could be about any ordinary American suburb, but the emotion behind her airy dream-pop makes it entirely personal.

title: Giving Birth to Thunder
label: Numero Group
description: An anthology of the emo pioneers’ complete works testifies to their thrift, their seriousness, and their towering legacy; it captures the essence of a crucial era in the genre’s history.

title: The Fall of Hobo Johnson
label: Reprise
description: The second album from the viral star is crowded with histrionic vocals, tired emotions, and petty grievances, leaving little room to actually enjoy his music.

title: Jimmy Lee
label: Columbia
description: The soul singer’s latest is a multi-perspective, multi-genre examination of addiction and family breakdown.

title: Ma
label: Nonesuch
description: On his most cohesive album in more than a decade, the re-energized songwriter imparts life lessons to the child he may never have.

title: None More Negative
label: Roadrunner
description: The confrontational Brooklyn-based goth-metal outfit get a decadent box set that celebrates their sensuality and pathos as well as their uglier side.

title: All My Heroes Are Cornballs
label: EQT
description: The experimental rapper remains an impish writer and an athletic vocalist on his latest album, one that lays bare the sprawling collage in his fiery, fascinating brain.

title: The Highwomen
label: Low Country Sound
description: On a dozen songs that transcend stereotypes of women in country music, this supergroup explores love, politics, and family.

title: The Time for Peace Is Now
label: Luaka Bop
description: Luaka Bop’s collection of ’70s rhythmic gospel rarities doesn’t feel like gospel in the traditional sense. These working musicians were deeply entwined with the funky, soulful sounds of their time.

title: Adult Baby
label: Adult Baby
description: The lead singer and songwriter for Blonde Redhead enlists Ryuichi Sakamoto, Greg Saunier, and others for a cottony swirl of an album where everything is quieter than everything else.

title: Metronomy Forever
label: Because Music
description: A casual approach gives rise to some of the English electro-indie band’s best songs in years. But for anyone not already misty-eyed with nostalgia, a meandering 17-track album is a hard sell.

title: Beneath the Eyrie
label: Infectious
description: After the disappointing Indie Cindy and the serviceable Head Carrier, the band shows signs of recapturing some of the spark of their classic albums.

title: The Practice of Love
label: Sacred Bones
description: The Norwegian artist brings her heady, personal text into the world of dance music to create an affecting, transcendental album that lives on the boundary of pop and the avant-garde.

title: October Song
label: Marbled Arm
description: The gorgeous and hypnotic second Lightning Bug album focuses more than ever on songwriter Audrey Kang's hushed voice and simple, soulful lyrics.

title: House of Sugar
label: Domino
description: The enigmatic songwriter’s latest album is full of vignettes that shift to reveal and conceal themselves in ways too unpredictable to be easily faked. It might be his best yet.

title: Blacks’ Myths II
label: Atlantic Rhythms
description: On a thrilling slab of punk-jazz noise, the D.C. duo argues for the centrality of black American culture in the fight for the nation’s soul.

title: Utility
label: Ostgut Ton
description: For anyone who has ever fantasized about dissolving into the dancefloor, the debut solo album from techno artist Sam Barker is as close as it gets.

title: Sentimentally Yours
label: Decca
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the final album of Patsy Cline’s lifetime, a record that helped define country-pop.

title: Devour
label: Sacred Bones
description: With one of her most harrowing and powerful albums to date, Margaret Chardiet zeroes in on the locus where global horrors register on the individual.

title: Mirrorland
label: Dreamville
description: The debut album from Spillage Village founders Olu and WowGr8 is a whimsical, theatrical attempt to capture the inexhaustible magic of Atlanta.

title: Days of the Bagnold Summer (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Matador
description: The indie-pop veterans mix together classics, rarities, some new songs, and instrumentals for the original film soundtrack.

title: Something Like a War
label: Female Energy
description: Adam Bainbridge’s production is always tasteful and seldom bad, but is only great when heightened by its guests.

title: Lookout Low
label: Grand Jury
description: Chicago’s local heroes grow up a little on their fourth album and lose some of their live-wire charm in the process.

title: Hypersonic Missiles
label: Interscope
description: Though the upstart British songwriter is a capable storyteller when he zeroes on a single topic, his debut is only intermittently transcendent.

title: Charli
label: Atlantic
description: With adventurous production and revealing writing, Charli XCX’s third studio album reflects an artist ready to commit to self-examination.

title: Free
label: Loma Vista
description: On his meditative collaboration with the ambient guitarist Noveller and jazz trumpeter Leron Thomas, Iggy Pop turns inward.

title: Lifetime
label: ijn inc
description: On her most personal album to date, the UK experimental musician retains her focus on the ambiguities of the processed human voice while bringing traditional instrumentation to the fore.

title: When We Are Inhuman
label: 37d03d
description: These contemporary classical arrangements of traditional folk and Bonnie “Prince” Billy songs are lovely to listen to, but not so clear thematically.

title: Sun Rings
label: Nonesuch
description: Utilizing space recordings and scraps of poetry, the minimalist titan and his long-time collaborators grapple with humanity’s place in the universe.

title: The Blue EP
label: Atlantic
description: Save for a few intimate highlights, Ben Gibbard continues to move in lockstep with his band's bigger, bolder, more arena-ready sound.

title: The Competition
label: Ribbon Music
description: The sleek Baltimore synth-pop band's latest might be their most explicitly political and theoretical work, tackling nothing less than the socio-psychological ravages of capitalism.

title: Is He Real?
label: Clue
description: The major-label debut from the Maryland rapper clearly wants to appeal to the thinkers, but even at its most lucid, this loosely conceptual album falls well short of lofty ambitions.

title: Resonant Body
label: T4T LUV NRG
description: Maya Bouldry-Morrison’s album is a celebration of the qualities—intimacy, ambiguity, physicality, release—that lead to dancefloor catharsis.

title: The People I Love
label: Pi Recordings
description: Assisted by pianist Craig Taborn, the New York saxophonist’s longstanding trio balances minimalist stillness with post-bop freneticism, and covers Autechre and Jeff “Tain” Watts along the way.

title: Hollywood’s Bleeding
label: Republic
description: The divisive pop star still gets bogged down in melancholy, but the charm of Post Malone’s third album is in his versatile voice and his ability to make a great hook inside pretty much any song.

title: We Love You Tecca
label: Galactic
description: The 17-year-old Queens rapper went viral off a certified hit, but his debut project is repetitive and uninspired.

title: Monos (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Invada
description: Much like the UK composer’s score for Jonathan Glazer’s Under the Skin, Monos uses just a smattering of sounds to craft a world of deepening dread.

title: At the Party With My Brown Friends
label: Saddle Creek
description: Encased in swirls of dream-pop production, Katherine Paul’s second album represents a softer, more subtle sort of resistance.

title: Town Centre
label: Speedy Wunderground
description: The wonderfully anarchic British post-punk outfit tries out a little of everything on their promising debut EP.

title: Twelve Nudes
label: Bella Union
description: The songwriter’s most direct and brash album yet has no time for saxophones or keyboards. She gives specific, unpoetic examples and doesn’t mince words.

title: Close It Quietly
label: Sub Pop
description: On her fourth studio album, Greta Kline gamely stares down her middle twenties, that messy period where one’s early projections about the future tend to start unraveling.

title: Ingénue
label: Sire
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit k.d. lang’s landmark 1992 album, an emotive and daring reinvention for the former country singer.

title: Soft Landing
label: Constellation
description: This time, the perennially chill Toronto musician‘s second album in as many years focuses on the guitar across a slow-motion, beatific collection of songs.

title: Saves the World
label: RCA
description: Translating alt-rock into pristine pop, the L.A. trio’s second album documents sex, drugs, and suicidal tendencies with less melodrama and more compassion.

title: Wallop
label: Warp
description: The New York party monsters change course, embracing the sounds of the ’90s and getting in touch with their feelings.

title: Lost Girls
label: AWAL
description: Natasha Khan's latest is a synth-pop love letter to the ’80s sci-fi and fantasy films of her youth.

title: About Us
label: Future Classic
description: Georgia Flipo follows up her viral hit "About You" with a pop debut that hopes to re-bottle the song's charm.

title: -Ugh, those feels again
label: ARTium
description: On the sequel to 2017’s FEELS, the Iranian Swedish singer’s dramatic take on soul finally bears fruit.

title: Whities 023 (The Act of Falling From the 8th Floor)
label: Whities
description: Three years after their debut collaboration, the Egyptian singer/poet/trumpeter and the German electronic trio reunite for six haunting tracks of socio-political despair and existential dread.

title: Fear Inoculum
label: RCA
description: The prog metal band’s fifth album is exactly what you’d expect from a project over a decade in the making: a more mature, sometimes exciting collection that feels both overworked and undercooked.

title: Braindrops
label: Joyful Noise
description: The Melbourne punk quartet sift through the grubbiest entrails of politics and internet culture, but their perspective sounds stilted.

title: Let Love
label: Loma Vista
description: Common’s latest is a loungy meditation on love and its many forms. It is at turns hopeful and naive.

title: Free Company
label: Anti-
description: Taylor Vick, a prolific Oakland songwriter and multi-instrumentalist, has made a generous and gorgeously empathetic chronicle of the aftermath of love.

title: Saw You Up There
label: self-released
description: The Chicago punk trio disbanded in 2016, but their final album serves up the chaotic blend of post-hardcore, noise rock, and Midwest emo that made them beloved.

title: Dykes to Watch Out For
label: Get Better
description: Building on the legacy of ’90s riot grrrl and queercore, the Massachusetts punks’ debut album is a galvanizing thrill that insists on naming what some would ignore.

title: Like the River Loves the Sea
label: No Quarter

title: Forever Turned Around
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The Chicago band’s second album dials back their beaming, golden-hour soft rock to a gentle lull.

title: Norman Fucking Rockwell!
label: Polydor
description: On her elegant and complex fifth album, Lana Del Rey sings exquisitely of freedom and transformation and the wreckage of being alive. It establishes her as one of America’s greatest living songwriters.

title: Venus in Leo
label: Ghostly
description: The duo depicts moments of great longing and melancholy on their sensual and gloomy new album.

title: Kleinmeister
label: Orindal
description: With tranquil, careful compositions that encourage introspection, the Vermont musician reflects on climate anxiety without succumbing to doom and gloom.

title: Threads
label: The Valory Music Co.
description: The superstar’s eleventh studio album pairs her with famous friends ranging from Stevie Nicks to St. Vincent.

title: In My Lifetime, Vol. 1
label: Def Jam
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit JAY-Z’s second album, one that’s more gripping as a show of raw skill than it is as an act of myth-making.

title: Iconology EP
label: Atlantic
description: The pop music icon spends too much time looking back on a seemingly rushed, mostly forgettable collection of tracks.

title: LOVE AND AFFECTION FOR STUPID LITTLE BITCHES
label: self-released
description: Pop and noise make for strangely suited bedfellows on an album, by turns colorful and crushing, steeped in physical and psychic pain.

title: In the Spirit World Now
label: Relapse
description: After some nebulous false starts, the former hardcore band has finally found space to carve their own lane in the crowded field of ’80s-indebted groups.

title: nikolai reptile
label: Trip
description: Mirabella Karyanova’s debut EP for Nina Kraviz’s Trip label pairs playful Russian-language vocal manipulation with woozy electronic pop modeled after minimal techno’s trippy specifications.

title: May the Lord Watch
label: Nation
description: The North Carolina rap group (minus producer 9th Wonder) reunite for a warm, breezy LP that recalls the best of their original work.

title: Field Whispers (Into the Crystal Palace)
label: Orange Milk
description: Balancing vaporwave’s glossy kitsch with throat-shredding metal vocals and labyrinthine sound collage, Angel Marcloid’s music is a perfect fusion of pop and pure abstraction.

title: Master
label: RCA
description: The major-label debut from the Atlanta R&B singer offers a layered, mesmerizing portrait of modern romance.

title: Chasing Summer
label: Top Dawg
description: The TDE soul singer takes a darker turn on his second record, a sad and gauzy R&B collection full of bitterness and missed connections.

title: To Myself
label: Human Re Sources
description: With a voice that evokes Nina Simone’s, the 24-year-old Atlanta soul singer uses her debut album to explore post-breakup intimacies of pain and desire.

title: Trying to Find My Next Thrill
label: RCA
description: On his second album, the Boston rapper embraces his strengths, grows into his voice as a writer and draws lessons from his come-up.

title: Face Stabber
label: Castle Face
description: On their absorbing and endearing new double album, John Dwyer's long-running psych-rock institution verges on self-indulgence for the first time.

title: Back in the Tall Grass
label: self-released
description: The 25-year-old Norwegian musician is a chameleonic vocal force. Her debut cushions heartache in shadowy, serpentine melodies and shoegaze guitars.

title: 85 to Africa
label: Wondaland
description: On his latest, Jidenna invokes a metaphorical highway to Africa, uniting the sounds of the sprawling diaspora. The music ranges from booming contemporary hip-hop to feather-light afropop and highlife.

title: Anak Ko
label: Polyvinyl
description: Melina Duterte’s second album as Jay Som sounds exploratory and playful, like a jam session among friends that’s just hit its stride.

title: Free Cell
label: Captured Tracks
description: Titled after a game of computer solitaire, the Queens musician’s second album uses avant-pop songwriting to capture the nuances of tedium, to strangely captivating effect.

title: August
label: Sub Pop
description: A quiet resolve underlies the folk singer’s mesmeric Sub Pop debut, which is her sunniest and most intrepid.

title: Are You Sleepy
label: Elephant Six
description: This surreal, distortion-heavy power-pop album, reissued on vinyl, stands among the best of the late-’90s Elephant 6 output.

title: Eve
label: Roc Nation
description: Rapsody’s third record is a triumph. The North Carolina MC unlocks her full skillset and brings her creativity and ingenuity to the fore.

title: Release the Dogs
label: Merge
description: The solo debut from Wye Oak member Andy Stack threads kinetic dream-pop and electronic textures into a hypnotic break-up record.

title: How to Live
label: Bella Union
description: New band from former Ultimate Painting songwriter Jack Cooper blends introspective songwriting with churning experimentation in earnest search of a different plane of existence.

title: WAHALA
label: PTP
description: On their harrowing and strangely cleansing second album, the Brooklyn-based vocalist and poet grapples with depression, anxiety, and identity.

title: Lover
label: Republic
description: On her seventh album, Taylor Swift is a little wiser and a lot more in love. Though uneven, Lover is a bright, fun album with great emotional honesty.

title: Dutty Rock
label: Atlantic
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the arrival of Sean Paul, who brought dancehall with all its complexity to the masses.

title: A Distant Call
label: Wilsuns RC
description: The Philadelphia band return with a glorious sheen on their pro-worker, pro-barroom rock’n’roll.

title: Blue Days, Black Nights
label: Get Loud
description: The debut from Ivan Howard (Gayngs, Rosebuds) is a frivolous soufflé of soft-rock babymakers and disco deliria that could have been crafted any time in the last fifty years.

title: Total Solidarity
label: Oramics
description: A fundraiser for Polish LGBTQIA+ organizations presents a bounty of progressive electronic music, compiling 10 hours of material from Rrose, Violet, Peder Mannerfelt, and more.

title: River Without Banks
label: Unseen Worlds
description: The Hague-based composer and pianist explores music’s transcendent qualities on an album of minimalist piano with subtle new-age overtones.

title: Bunny
label: Orchid Tapes
description: On his third album, Sam Hall performs lo-fi keyboard-trap doused in the same ecstasy produced by fleeting interactions with your middle-school crush.

title: GINGER
label: Question Everything
description: After a brief hiatus, the restlessly creative group returns with a compelling but disjointed record about self-fulfillment.

title: A Healthy Earth
label: Tiny Engines
description: The slowcore band’s knotty and fascinating third LP delves into the question of what makes daily life so unnecessarily difficult.

title: Envejeciendo
label: Cascine
description: The Ecuador-born songwriter’s second album is a study in time, examining aging as a continuum of death and regeneration with a light, whimsical touch.

title: You Made It This Far
label: Father/Daughter
description: On her sophomore album, the country singer name-checks Minor Threat and Against Me! while drawing inspiration from classic Hank Williams and Patsy Cline.

title: Animated Violence Mild
label: Sacred Bones
description: The Fuck Buttons member’s fourth solo album channels the horrors of the surveillance state and the creeping dread of everyday life into the most aggressive music of his career.

title: Death Drive EP
label: Deathbomb Arc
description: The Vancouver-based producer/vocalist is a merciless industrial-rap experimentalist obsessed with the point where sex and death intertwine.

title: Thrashing Thru the Passion
label: Frenchkiss
description: The Brooklyn indie rock institution’s seventh album is as joyous and rousing as their best efforts.

title: Love’s Last Chance
label: AWAL
description: The Los Angeles-based producer and composer adds singing to his repertoire, setting snapshots of past romances against warm, nostalgic production.

title: Control the Streets, Volume 2
label: Quality Control
description: The Atlanta label home to Migos and Lil Yachty overstuffs their new compilation with lackluster raps from stars who seem to be stuck in a loop.

title: So Much Fun
label: 300 Entertainment
description: Featuring several of his acolytes, So Much Fun remains a triumphant showcase for the iconoclastic Young Thug and one of his best albums to date.

title: Black Moses EP
label: Godmode
description: Pairing Midwestern hip-house with Los Angeles G-funk, the South Central native emphasizes subtly bumping grooves and gruff, hypnotic rhymes.

title: Inflorescent
label: Casablanca
description: The UK trio's first album since 2011 finds new life in the smooth surfaces of house music.

title: UFO
label: Fool's Gold
description: In accordance with his label’s ethos, the Fool’s Gold co-founder connects the dots between the hip-hop and dance worlds on a space-themed record that bounces from rap to rave to electro.

title: The Center Won’t Hold
label: Mom & Pop
description: St. Vincent’s sleek, streamlined production stands out from the rest of the band’s catalog, but all of the elements you first fell in love with are still here.

title: Speak Now
label: Big Machine
description: Swift’s third album is her most unabashedly transitional work: between childhood and adulthood, innocence and understanding, country and pop.

title: Red
label: Big Machine
description: The spectacular Red transformed pop and country music around it. It remains the pinnacle of Taylor Swift’s career, an intimate album of disappearances and lost relationships.

title: Fearless
label: Big Machine
description: On her second album, Taylor Swift straddles the line between country and pop. Still new to Nashville, she took her teen self seriously and demanded others do the same.

label: Big Machine
description: On her fifth album, Swift loses her naïveté. It’s her full turn into pop, a savvy move from a superstar thrust into the spotlight.

title: Taylor Swift
label: Big Machine
description: In her breakthrough debut, a teenage Swift showed all the qualities that she would eventually use to conquer the world.

title: Heart Like a Wheel
label: Capitol
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a landmark of mainstream ’70s soft-rock, the peak of Linda Ronstadt’s power as a singer nonpareil.

title: I Spent the Winter Writing Songs About Getting Better
label: Big Scary Monsters
description: The Brooklyn band's explosively verbal, shapeshifting, and snarky emo-pop explores how intersectional identities move within predominantly white spaces.

title: Infest the Rats’ Nest
label: Flightless
description: On their second album of the year, the ever-mutating Aussie psych-rock outfit embrace throwback thrash metal to soundtrack the end of life on Earth.

title: STUMM433
label: Mute
description: As part of its 40th-anniversary celebrations, the Mute label commissions 58 covers of 4:33, John Cage’s notorious “silent” piece, from New Order, Depeche Mode, and other staples of the roster.

title: Basking in the Glow
label: Triple Crown
description: The excellent album from the Long Island singer-songwriter Jade Lilitri is sharp and radiant, a massively catchy guitar record about trying to walk the straight and narrow.

title: Sweet Princess EP
label: self-released
description: These six cerebral, spiky songs extract something touching and tragic from the mundanity of social media and social anxiety.

title: Other Girls
label: Third Man
description: On her second album, the Nashville spitfire flits easily between country, bluegrass, and rock.

title: Equivalents
label: Kranky
description: Inspired by Alfred Stieglitz’ black-and-white photographs of clouds, the Canadian ambient musician reworks piano samples into one of the most monochromatic albums of his career.

title: This Is Not a Safe Place
label: Wichita
description: On their second post-reunion album, the shoegaze band sound emboldened, merrily tinkering with their legacy.

title: Jambú e Os Míticos Sons Da Amazônia
label: Analog Africa
description: This revelatory survey of the music of Northern Brazil from the 1970s and ’80s is by turns alien and familiar, sacred and profane, always raw and thrilling.

title: forevher
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The pop singer’s second album is looser, livelier and more ecstatic than her debut, detailing the headlong rush of falling in love.

title: Black Love & War
label: SomeOthaShip Connect
description: Equal parts manifesto and critique, the pair’s third musical collaboration pays homage to the sound and radical spirit of their West Coast home.

title: We Are Not Your Kind
label: Roadrunner
description: The sixth album from the Iowa metal mainstays has more to offer than expected and is still sometimes frustratingly short-sighted.

title: Bumps & Bruises
label: Asylum
description: The meme rapper’s debut album confirms everyone’s suspicions about the relationship between viral hip-hop fame and rapping abilities.

title: So Divine
label: Run for Cover
description: On their second album, the Boston slowcore trio’s pensive, downtempo rock has grown tighter, clearer, and at times brighter.

title: Port of Miami 2
label: Maybach Music Group
description: Age has mellowed rap’s most audacious fabulist, and on the sequel to his breakout debut he settles into his luxe sound like a pair of velvet slippers.

title: Blinded by the Light (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Columbia
description: The coming-of-age film reveals the life-changing power of some of Bruce Springsteen’s most famous songs, but its soundtrack doesn’t measure up.

title: Perfumed Earth
label: Flying Nun
description: The New Zealand sister duo offer a self-contained suite of dream pop, folk, and cosmic jazz that’s far more evocative than the few words they sing.

label: 10K Projects
description: Trippie Redd’s sprawling album is designed to show his versatility, but it’s not nearly wild enough to distract from its lack of coherent ideas.

title: Melt Away
label: VLF Records
description: The masked UK duo crafts electronic pop that draws on hip-hop, R&B, chillwave, and psych-funk, but their immersive soundscapes leave little impression.

title: Live 1969
label: RCA
description: In 1969, Elvis Presley went to Las Vegas to reboot his career. With a half-century of hindsight, the performances feel both bittersweet and anticlimactic.

title: Mushrooms & Coloring Books
label: Sick Wid It
description: On his new mixtape, the Vallejo upstart sounds a little too eager to break out of his home base.

title: 11 Items
label: West Mineral Ltd.
description: The latest on the adventurous West Mineral Ltd. label finds the mysterious duo crafting something with classic ambient earmarks as well as off-kilter addenda.

title: Superbloom
label: Caroline
description: Their latest album aims for life-or-death melodrama, but amid the layered arrangements and slick songwriting, Ra Ra Riot seem to once again have lost their sense of identity.

title: Buckingham Nicks
label: Polydor
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the calm before the storm, a long-out-of-print album from Lindsey Buckingham and Stevie Nicks before they joined Fleetwood Mac.

title: Any Human Friend
label: Sub Pop
description: The British singer-songwriter’s third album is a singular, extraordinarily horny, and occasionally bleak pop record largely about the complexities of queer desire.

title: The Search
label: NFREALMUSIC
description: With a persona modeled after Eminem’s, the Michigan-born star of Christian rap recently notched his second No. 1 album. But to most of the secular world, he’s a ghost.

title: The Soft Cavalry
label: Bella Union
description: Though the ethereal presence of Slowdive’s Rachel Goswell is unmistakable, the UK band’s self-titled debut is often tedious.

title: Coastal Erosion
label: Ideal
description: Balancing lush ambience and sharp electronics, this cross-continental collaboration addresses the climate crisis with musical interpretations of land under assault.

title: floral print EP
label: Tiny Engines
description: On their second EP, the Atlanta trio swirls post-punk, drone, and math rock into self-described “deconstructionist pop.”

title: i,i
label: Jagjaguwar
description: On his fourth album, Justin Vernon reassembles the familiar Bon Iver elements like a cubist collage, with his voice fearlessly front and center. The result is his most honest and forthright music ever.

title: Inna Duppy SKRS Soundclash
label: Duppy Gun
description: Duppy Gun’s latest, organized around the songs of I Jahbar, finds the Jamaican crew boldly charting their own course.

title: Wide Prairie
label: MPL
description: Linda McCartney’s first and only studio album was released to resounding silence shortly after her death in 1998. But she and Paul shared a musical chemistry as singular as Yoko and John’s, and as emblematic of their shared interests.

title: Live on Ice
label: EMPIRE
description: Inspired by a love of fantasy and cartoons, the rapper’s debut full-length is simultaneously playful and sincere, confident and anxious.

title: Blue 05 / Blue 06
label: Whities Blue
description: A pair of new singles from London’s Whities label demonstrate that there are few better places to take the pulse of adventurous UK club music.

title: Dum and Dummer
label: Paper Route Empire
description: Independent rap vet Young Dolph trades bars with fellow Memphis native Key Glock on an album that channels the city’s iconic sound.

title: The Sailor
label: 88rising
description: On his second album, the viral rap star makes some of the most charming music of his still-young career.

title: AOKOHIO
label: Joyful Noise
description: Yoni Wolf and his band switch up their approach with bite-sized songs, a visual album, and an uncharacteristic focus on the past.

title: Abraxas EP
label: Ancient Astronauts
description: The breakbeat revivalist returns to well-worn rave tropes, yielding diminishing returns.

title: Live at Troxy
label: Mute
description: The live album captures a night of the exuberant collaboration Karin Dreijer fostered with the Plunge stage production, adding volume and dimensionality to old and new songs alike.

title: Blume
label: Domino
description: The rowdy and promising debut from this London septet is further evidence of the London jazz scene’s vitality.

title: Parted Plains
label: Leaving
description: The Baltimore ambient musician uses sitar and synthesizers to investigate folkloric narratives from around the world.

title: Care Package
label: OVO Sound
description: This odds-and-ends compilation features tracks originally released between 2010 and 2016, and presents a more vulnerable version of the pop colossus we know now.

title: Good Morning Cruel World
label: GOTHBOICLIQUE
description: With live instrumentation and a hard-won sense of optimism, the GothBoiClique artist’s official debut makes a case for itself in the pop-punk lineage.

title: Data Horde
label: Peak Oil
description: On his first full-length under the Leech alias, Brian Foote dissects his electronic music until it evokes the wide-open spaces of early drum’n’bass.

title: First Taste
label: Drag City
description: Temporarily abandoning the guitar, the prolific garage rocker channels his indulgences and comes away with an unusually focused album.

title: GUV I
label: Run for Cover
description: Fucked Up guitarist Ben Cook is also a pop poet, and the third album from his nostalgic indie-pop project recalls the grainy, jangly melodicism of college rock.

title: Country Squire
label: Hickman Holler
description: The native Kentuckian shows a flair for rough-hewn honky-tonk and piercing details on his latest release, produced by Sturgill Simpson.

title: Stevie Wonder’s Journey Through the Secret Life of Plants
label: Tamla
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Stevie Wonder’s sprawling, misunderstood double album about the interconnections of ecology and the black experience.

title: Dragonfly
label: Closed Sessions
description: The Chicago rapper fills his debut with raps about...making it in rap. It’s rarely endearing or interesting.

title: The Tennessee Fire: 20th Anniversary Edition
label: Darla
description: On their debut, My Morning Jacket discovered the heavy reverb that would make them legendary.

title: Practice Makes Paper
label: Heavy on the Grind
description: On his latest double album, the Vallejo vet remains free-flowing, wise, hilarious, and unstoppable.

title: Love Songs 4 the Streets 2
label: Alamo
description: A sequel to his 2017 tape shows the one-time rising star of Chicago drill again offering a sobering depiction of life outside of rap myths.

title: Safe and Also No Fear
label: Lame-O
description: On his third album, Jake Ewald reunites with former Modern Baseball bandmate Ian Farmer to explore pared-down folk-rock. It’s the furthest from MoBo he’s ever sounded.

title: Woodstock – Back to the Garden: The Definitive 50th Anniversary Archive
label: Rhino
description: Fifty years after the three-day concert made rock’n’roll history, a gargantuan, 38-disc set attempts to tell the full story of the event for the very first time.

title: Immunity
label: Fader
description: On her debut album, the young viral star moves beyond the lo-fi bedroom-pop of her early recordings and into a restrained, detailed style of songwriting all her own.

title: Live From the Artists Den
label: UME
description: This focused and forceful 2013 live set showed the reunited grunge band looking to their future before the tragic death of lead singer Chris Cornell.

title: African Giant
label: Atlantic
description: The Nigerian singer blends the personal and political into a new benchmark of Afro-fusion music.

title: Family Party EP
label: Sister Polygon
description: The Washington, D.C. trio make visceral, minimal punk that’s as stripped down as a roadkill carcass, and almost as gross.

title: Falling
label: Hardly Art
description: The Seattle pop-punk band shape-shifts through ‘90s alt-rock but sacrifices its personality in the process.

title: Once Upon a Time ... in Hollywood (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Columbia
description: The music is a highlight of Quentin Tarantino’s new film, an undeniable, oft-disquieting mixtape of golden-age rock’n’roll, radio DJ patter, and period-specific commercials.

title: Kiri Variations
label: Throttle
description: Elaborating on music he composed for the British TV series “Kiri,” the Warp Records mainstay vacillates between too-tasteful acoustic arrangements and abrasive provocation.

label: Motown
description: Unlike some of R&B’s showier personalities, the Chicago singer makes do with a great voice, laid-back vibes, and a classic sound that’s neither brazenly modern nor self-consciously retro.

title: Meet the Woo
label: Victor Victor
description: The Brooklyn rapper makes good on the promise of “Welcome to the Party” with a debut full of the hardest, dirtiest tracks he can manage.

title: Carnival
label: Sire
description: The debut full-length from the “Drew Barrymore” singer isn’t designed for conscious, focused listening. This is music for poolsides and basements.

title: Remembering the Rockets
label: Tiny Engines
description: The best album of the Philadelphia band’s deep and underappreciated catalog dares to ask what comes after indie rock.

title: The Big Day
label: self-released
description: Chance’s sprawling, 77-minute “debut” is an exuberant and often wonderful celebration of love and family that struggles to bring depth to his newlywed dad-raps.

title: Live at Alexandra Palace London, 8th and 9th May 2019
label: Text
description: Kieran Hebden’s new live album reminds us that he is a stellar performer, not just a producer.

title: Emily Alone
label: Double Double Whammy
description: Emily Sprague’s folk music turns solitude into an evocation of spirits. Her latest album as Florist grapples with change, death, and uncertainty with some of the most arresting songwriting of the year.

title: Feel My Love
label: Be With
description: A sought-after roller-disco anthem from 1983 makes for a tantalizing hybrid of boogie, electro, and house, and lays the foundation for artists from Chromeo to Dâm-Funk.

title: De Lorians
label: Beyond Beyond is Beyond
description: The Tokyo jazz-fusion quintet specializes in disorienting twists and turns, offsetting chaos with an unmistakable sense of fun.

title: The Lost Boy
label: ART@WAR
description: Occasionally corny and self-serious, Cordae's redemption tale shows a promising voice bursting into the mainstream.

title: Moon Pix
label: Matador
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Chan Marshall’s spellbinding fourth album, an intimate and feverish masterpiece from the singer-songwriter.

title: Angels on the Slope
label: Luminelle
description: The debut solo album from Pavo Pavo’s Eliza Bagg, a collection of pop songs with subtle experimental undertones, is her most outré release to date.

title: Immaculada High
label: Relapse
description: The fabled noise-rock outfit paint an ugly world on their second post-reunion release, but they have never sounded freer or more purposeful.

title: 1000 gecs
label: Dog Show
description: The duo’s wild-eyed genre mishmash covers chiptune’d pop-punk, chintzy trance synths, and the closely mic’d intimacy of indie pop—sometimes all in the same song.

title: Fraudulent Activity
label: self-released
description: The latest mixtape from the young Detroit rapper takes scamming to the next level.

title: Para Mí
label: Interscope
description: The 21-year-old bedroom-pop artist’s major-label debut displays shaggy charm and an eclecticism that’s still confined to the more pleasant parts of the color wheel.

title: Under the Shade
label: self-released
description: The 21-year-old Bronx native belongs to an exciting new generation remaking NYC rap in their own image. On his third album, he grapples with present-day poverty and everyday life.

title: Resavoir
label: International Anthem
description: The Chicago trumpeter with hip-hop and indie-rock bona fides steps out as a bandleader, shepherding 18 musicians across a complex, soulful album that celebrates interconnectedness.

title: In My Defense
label: Bad Dreams
description: The Australian rapper returns with her first album in five years, sounding not just unrepentant but also tediously uninterested in growing or challenging herself.

title: Caligula
label: Profound Lore
description: On her torrential second album, Kristin Hayter creates a murderous amalgam of opera, metal, and noise that uses her classical training like a Trojan Horse, burning misogyny to ash from its Judeo-Christian roots.

title: Remind Me: The Classic Elektra Recordings 1978-1984
label: Strut
description: The jazz and R&B legend's songs have been sampled by everyone from Will Smith to Prince Paul. This compilation shows her immaculate work on its own.

title: Willow
label: MSFTS MUSIC
description: The latest album from the child star turned Star Child can be pretty in a tuned-out sort of way, but her psychedelic soul music is no closer to showing us who she really is.

title: Songs From San Mateo County
label: Smoking Room
description: Tony Molina’s fat-free, minute-long missives give you everything you might want in a rock song in a third of the time. This rarities collection is the perfect entry point.

title: A People’s History of Gauche
label: Merge
description: Featuring members of Priests and Downtown Boys, the D.C. punk collective’s debut is a driving and tenacious record that never loses its feral appeal.

title: The Lost Tapes 2
label: Mass Appeal
description: Originally meant for a 2003 release, these unreleased songs from Nas’ latter-day output pale in comparison to the rapper’s greatest work.

title: Moon: The Area of Influence
label: Axis
description: Tilting his gaze toward the heavens once again, the Detroit electronic icon delivers an ambient-techno concept album exploring the moon’s pull on the human imagination.

title: stranno stranno. neobjatno.
label: Trip
description: The Russian electronic musician offers a mind-melting and hypnotic take on techno.

title: Planetary Clairvoyance
label: 20 Buck Spin
description: The Toronto death metal quartet push outward into new territory on their darkest, strangest album yet.

title: The Lion King: The Gift
label: Walt Disney
description: Beyoncé parlays her role in Disney’s The Lion King to put out a fine companion album that showcases today’s African stars.

title: King’s Mouth
label: Warner Bros.
description: As far as concept albums about magical, abnormally sized severed heads go, this is a pretty breezy listen.

title: Black Wave
label: FDH
description: Jay Reatard’s early band Lost Sounds veered from rock‘n’roll primitivism into synth-punk futurism, but the result wasn’t dance music—it was panic music.

title: Rogue Intruder, Soul Enhancer
label: Bloom
description: Following a standout contribution to Berlin label PAN’s Mono No Aware compilation, the Stockholm producer delivers an impressive debut album that’s both gloomy and delightful.

title: Grace EP
label: Hyperdub
description: In the wake of a family tragedy, the producer crafts a genuinely transportive work, seamlessly mixing Jersey club with Middle Eastern instruments.

title: Harlem World
label: Bad Boy
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the debut album from Mase, an icon of the shiny suit era who turned the Bad Boy throne into a recliner.

title: Tiny Changes: A Celebration of Frightened Rabbit’s ‘The Midnight Organ Fight’
label: Atlantic
description: Completed before the death of Frightened Rabbit’s Scott Hutchison, this tribute to the band’s most celebrated album takes a relaxed, occasionally unconventional approach.

title: Apollo: Atmospheres & Soundtracks - Extended Edition
label: UMC
description: The 1983 film score aspired to the weightlessness of outer space. A remastered edition adds an album’s worth of new songs that reflect how far we’ve come from the Apollo missions’ optimism.

title: Next to the Sun
label: Sooper
description: The daring Chicago pop artist explores resilience and hard-won triumphs against a backdrop of hatred and brutality.

title: Pity Boy
label: Don Giovanni
description: The New York singer-songwriter shifts from acoustic folk into potent pop-punk that recalls both Hop Along and Titus Andronicus.

title: Brandon Banks
label: Big Persona
description: Sordid family history has long been the source of the Houston rapper’s most resonant storytelling. His latest project is such a major leap in craft and style, it becomes a superpower.

title: Emperor Tomato Ketchup
label: Duophonic
description: Their fourth album revealed the band to be unparalleled pop architects. They were brilliant in the studio, crafting groovy, socialist call-to-actions with a sound from out of time and place.

title: Peng!
label: Too Pure
description: Far from the knotty time signatures and intricate textures of their later work, Stereolab’s debut album captures a shoegaze-besotted indie-pop band figuring out exactly who it wants to be.

title: Mars Audiac Quintet
label: Duophonic
description: Stereolab's third album, the hardest-rocking and most hypnotic music the band ever set to tape, is the closest they came to replicating the jet-engine roar of their live shows.

title: Low Fi EP
label: Too Pure
description: Issued just four months after their debut, the underrated 25-minute EP is a glorious distillation of their early sound, about harnessing the noise and directing it even if you can never hope to tame it.

title: Transient Random-Noise Bursts With Announcements
label: Duophonic
description: The deep, distorted grooves of Stereolab’s second album mark the middle of their motorik period, an incantatory album with a darkly lit sound as if everyone played with their eyes closed.

title: K.R.I.T. IZ HERE
label: Multi Alumni
description: The southern rapper’s latest project captures him the same way he always is: perfectly likable, admirably sincere, predictably dependable and dependably predictable.

title: what we say in private
label: Saddle Creek
description: The Montreal singer-songwriter’s debut album uses heartbreak as the springboard for an innovative brand of indie rock that’s both fiery and introspective.

title: III
label: Harvest
description: While the brooding pop singer can’t always shake the anodyne songwriting that plagued her past work, III is still Banks’ best album to date.

title: Angel’s Pulse
label: Domino
description: Dev Hynes’ new mixtape feels light and loose, a pre-production sketchbook presented as a charmingly finished product with the help of several key guests.

title: No.6 Collaborations Project
label: Atlantic
description: The pop star’s compilation features Cardi B, Chance the Rapper, and Stormzy in a sometimes nice but hopelessly transparent attempt at a hip-hop crossover.

title: Amplified Heart
label: Buzzin' Fly
description: Though their 1994 album became most famous for a surprise hit remix, Tracey Thorn and Ben Watt’s spare, pensive style never sounded more fully realized than here.

title: Admission
label: Relapse
description: The metal band’s latest album retains the sludgy ferocity of their best work while opening up to include elements of shoegaze and dream-pop, to mixed success.

title: Don’t You Think You've Had Enough?
label: Dead Oceans
description: The Los Angeles punk duo get sober and burn off the fog of their last release for a crisper, punchier sound.

title: CASE STUDY 01
label: Golden Child
description: The Toronto singer croons his way into a sapiosexual world of love and philosophy, though not without controversy.

title: Tracing Back the Radiance
label: Mexican Summer
description: The experimental ambient musician's latest work is his most beatific and generous yet. It features a rotating cast of musicians, and feels like it is hovering off of the ground.

title: Hasta el Cielo
label: Dead Oceans
description: An album’s worth of dub versions of last year’s Con Todo El Mundo offer playful, if inessential, tweaks to the Houston band’s psych-funk sound.

title: Rouge
label: Verve Forecast
description: The Malaysian-born, L.A.-based musician moves away from folk-pop into simmering R&B, with features from Tyler, the Creator, Little Simz, and others.

title: Aaliyah
label: Blackground
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Aaliyah’s final album, her masterpiece.

title: Stranger Things: Soundtrack From the Netflix Original Series, Season 3
label: Sony
description: Madonna, “Weird Al” Yankovic, and a bizarre remix of the Who are all part of a soundtrack that speaks to the usual critiques of the frothy, summertime sci-fi tale.

title: SO EMOTIONAL
label: Hello!
description: Everyone in hip-hop roots for Atlanta rapper Key! His summery follow-up to last year’s break-out 777 offers more evidence why.

title: Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?
label: September Recordings
description: The Liverpool four-piece’s debut experiments liberally with pop’s conventions, taking a collage-like approach to chopped samples, ghostly harmonies, and pedal-driven guitars and keyboards.

title: Cease & Desist
label: Stones Throw
description: The frenetic, sample-heavy album from Eric Andre’s clown alter-ego is hard to take seriously, which is probably the point.

title: II
label: Efficient Space
description: The latest from the Melbourne electronic duo is a dawdler’s paradise, a daydream mapped to MIDI.

title: Purple Mountains
label: Drag City
description: David Berman’s first new music in over a decade is a marvelous collection of heartbreak, grief, and bitterness. His careful writing has never sounded so exacting or direct.

title: Then I Try Some More
label: Team Love
description: Sternberg’s debut balances stark themes of suicidal ideation, abject hopelessness, and self-hatred with whimsy and redemptive tenderness.

title: ERYS
label: MSFTS MUSIC
description: The young polymath’s latest album is mostly a slog, the sound of an artist with a blurry vision and too many resources at his disposal.

title: Cosmic Thrill Seekers
label: Counter Intuitive
description: The Albany emo band offer us a fuck-up’s masterpiece, a hero’s journey following a guy who might conquer the world if he could leave his couch.

title: Mr. Muthafuckin’ eXquire
label: Chocolate Rabbit
description: Eight years after “Huzzah,” the Brooklyn rapper is back on his own label, back on his own terms, and just as defiant and provocative as ever.

title: Who is experimental music?
label: self-released
description: Looping and manipulating voices into strange, lumbering beatbox fugues, Inga Copeland undercuts expectation at every turn.

title: Eternal Children
label: Equiknoxx Music
description: On their third album, the first release on their own label, Jamaica continue to find their voice; this time with vocals.

title: I'm Losing Myself
label: I, Voidhanger
description: Kameron Bogges makes one-man black metal that charts the hellish exhilarations and debilitating lows of bipolar disorder.

title: Midsommar (Original Score)
label: Milan
description: Bobby Krlic (aka the Haxan Cloak) scores Ari Aster’s nightmarish new film Midsommar, and the result is transfixing, gorgeous, and terrifying at once.

title: The ‘Mercury’ Demos
label: Rhino
description: A new installment in Parlophone’s ongoing reissue series revisits an oft-bootlegged 1969 session with fellow folkie John Hutchinson: literal bedroom tapes, but still revelatory.

title: The Flower and the Vessel
label: Shelter Press
description: The methodical arrangements and uncomfortably close whispers of the experimental French musician, poet, and visual artist bring us further inside her surreal world.

title: Revenge of the Dreamers III
label: Dreamville
description: The first spoils of the fabled Dreamville sessions feature J. Cole and his label mostly thriving in a collaborative environment.

title: STONECHILD
label: Memphis Industries
description: With subtle electronic production tugging at the edges of her fingerpicked folk, the California singer-songwriter peers at the dark side of motherhood.

title: Dawnbreaker
label: Nonesuch
description: The solo debut from folk singer Alexandra Sauser-Monnig reveals her effortless skill as a songwriter as she delivers an homage to the betwixt and between of a relationship in its twilight.

title: playroom
label: In Real Life
description: An artist known for his photographs turns his hand to music; his hazy, lo-fi productions strive for the analog warmth of his portraits, but they lack his pictures’ intimacy and empathy.

title: Building Bridges
label: Aus
description: The German house producer’s sound is warm and welcoming, fusing four-to-the-floor grooves with the spacious atmospheres of Jamaican dub.

title: Waves
label: Loantaka
description: On her debut, the French-American musician offers a broken heart, a jaded eye, oceans of surf-rock reverb, and a Van Dyke Parks cameo.

title: Simian Angel
label: Editions Mego
description: The Australian multi-instrumentalist pushes his wispy electroacoustic music into warmer, more melodic territory.

title: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time
label: Nintendo
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a globetrotting fantasia on the Nintendo 64 that remains the high-water mark for video game music.

title: Mother Earth’s Plantasia
label: Sacred Bones
description: This Moog synth album from 1972 was meant to help houseplants grow. Jury’s out on that, but it became a cult classic, newly reissued.

title: Bird Songs of a Killjoy
label: Spacebomb
description: Azniv Korkejian’s folk music boasts a surreal calm and a lived-in glow that masks turmoil just outside the frame.

title: BTS World: Original Soundtrack
label: BigHit Entertainment
description: The soundtrack to the superstar boy band’s mobile app game is the most inessential BTS-affiliated project to date.

title: OASIS
label: Universal Music Latino
description: The two urbano superstars bro down over trap and dembow beats on a goofy but incredibly fun summertime album.

title: Dolphine
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Erin Birgy’s fifth album feels like the heartfelt expression of a uniquely weird viewpoint. It flits from groovy jazz to psych-pop to sylvan folk with freaky glee.

title: Clarity
label: BunHead
description: The pop star’s debut is decadent and deeply silly, with songs delivered by the kind of person who uses even the slightest bit of emotional turmoil as an excuse to immerse herself in sex, drugs, and money.

title: A Loss Permitted...
label: Thirty Three Thirty Three
description: A live recording from 2016 captures the avant-rock titans jamming on the edge of oblivion.

title: I Was Real
label: Thin Wrist
description: The experimental New York duo morph into a crack ensemble on their wide-ranging new double album, blurring genres and record-store categories.

title: The Fleeting Light of Impermanence
label: Graveface
description: On their first new album in six years, the longrunning emo outfit take ownership of their sound. Even the quietest moments sit with jagged nerves and lingering tension.

title: DJ-Kicks
label: !K7
description: The Korean DJ’s contribution to the storied mix series looks beyond the dancefloor, offering a tantalizing peek at her influences.

title: “Let’s Rock”
label: Easy Eye Sound
description: This is an album by the Black Keys called “Let’s Rock.” That's what it does.

title: Digital Kabar: Electronic Maloya From La Réunion Since 1980
label: Infiné
description: A traditional, once-suppressed style from La Réunion, a small island off the coast of Madagascar, meets the electronic music of the 21st century.

title: Black Pumas
label: ATO
description: The Austin-based duo don’t shy away from signifiers of the past, conjuring the sounds of the late 1960s and early 1970s without succumbing to pure nostalgic pandering.

title: Sinner
label: KDJ
description: The elusive Detroit producer returns after a years-long mysterious absence with a burning, urgent, and immersive new LP.

title: Foam
label: Winspear
description: The Chicago band’s first full-length is a collection of sweet, brightly colored love songs from the mind of an acid enthusiast, woven from a small used record store’s worth of influences.

title: Ágætis byrjun
label: Krunk
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Sigur Rós’ elemental 1999 breakthrough.

title: Taxi Sampler 01: Rhythms & Vibes From the Spirit of Young Africa
label: Python Syndicate
description: The eclectic comp from the Rome-based collective Crudo Volta is a solid primer for those new to gqom, Afrobass, and Ethiopiyawi Electronic.

title: Radish
label: self-released
description: Experimental pianist Nathan Phillips flits seamlessly between wobbly electronic pop, soaring post-rock grandeur, and ambient minimalism.

title: Bandana
label: Keep Cool
description: On their second album as a duo, Madlib and Freddie Gibbs pull themselves deeper into one another’s worlds.

title: Tears of Joy
label: 10k
description: The Bronx rapper drags himself back and forth between agony and breakthrough on his latest record, the fullest and most realized album of the 20-year-old’s career.

title: Raving Disco Breaks Vol. 1
label: T4T LUV NRG
description: Inspired by house music’s roots in the queer and black communities of her hometown, the Chicago DJ delivers a DJ set joyfully at odds with the dominant strains of contemporary dance music.

title: Late Night Feelings
label: RCA
description: Produced by Mark Ronson and performed and co-written by a suite of female vocalists, this compilation explores the many shades of heartbreak in current pop.

title: The Life of Pi’erre 4
label: SossHouse
description: Playboi Carti's go-to producer goes solo, crooning in AutoTune over his blissfully simple earworm beats.

title: Commit Yourself Completely
label: Matador
description: Will Toledo takes Car Seat Headrest out of the bedroom and into a 1000-seat theater near you on the band’s first major live album.

title: Keepsake
label: Double Double Whammy
description: Hatchie's platonic ideal of dream pop goes down a bit too easy, like another rewatch of a John Hughes film.

title: ANIMA
label: XL
description: The third solo album from Thom Yorke is the first one that feels complete without his band behind him. It floats through the uneasy space between societal turmoil and internal monologue.

title: All the Mirrors In the House (Home Recordings 1979 - 1986)
label: Disciples
description: Fueled by the curiosity of the untutored mind, Warren Defever’s collection of childhood recordings is wispy, mercurial, and improbably good.

title: Help Us Stranger
label: Third Man
description: After an 11-year hiatus, the first album from Jack White’s other other band floats in weightless, haughty bliss through a perpetual 2008.

title: Text While Driving If You Want to Meet God
label: PLZ Make It Ruins
description: The Frank Ocean collaborator lays his hard drive bare, pulling back the curtain to reveal the scattered pieces of recorded music littering his cutting-room floor.

title: Dusk to Dawn
label: Twilight Enterprise
description: The Swedish producer and frequent Robyn collaborator offers an ambitious three-album suite of understated, occasionally disquieting techno nocturnes.

title: M3
label: Warner Bros.
description: The rap zeitgeist has mostly left Makonnen behind, but his first major-label release in years shows a taste of the pop star he could still become.

title: Gold & Grey
label: Abraxan Hymns
description: Post-rock, space rock, prog rock, psychedelic rock, grungy Alice in Chains-eyeing hard rock—it’s all here, and since it’s Baroness, it works.

title: Ride Me Back Home
label: Legacy
description: Old age suits the country singer well. On his latest album—featuring three newly penned tunes—Willie sings with a kind of chagrinned humor, as if nobody is more surprised by his longevity than he is.

title: Dreems
label: Love Supreme
description: Released just days after Philippe Zdar’s accidental death, the duo’s fifth album marks a joyous return to the emotive, immaculately produced house music of their early years.

title: ​Schlagenheim
label: Rough Trade
description: The London guitar band’s debut is twitchy, hair-raising, always on the move. They harken back to a more esoteric era of indie with a magnetic and dazzling style.

title: The End of Radio
label: Touch and Go
description: Culled from the band’s sessions at Maida Vale Studios in 1994 and 2004, this double-LP that captures, in great fidelity, the acerbic personality and power of Steve Albini’s trio.

title: Work
label: West End
description: The New York duo jump-starts iconic disco label West End Records with a love letter to classic dance, but the mood is strangely sour.

title: Patience
label: Epitaph
description: On their third record, the Philly band has achieved a balance between seething chaos and quietly devastating vulnerability. It’s one of the best punk rock records of the year.

title: Fog FM
label: Incienso
description: Tough, upfront, and often bruisingly physical, Fog FM is the New York producer’s most substantial piece of work by a considerable margin.

title: On Avery Island
label: Merge
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the oft-overshadowed debut from indie rock icons, a smaller and more intimate look into the mercurial world of Jeff Mangum.

title: III
label: Loma Vista
description: Kevin Devine and Manchester Orchestra’s Andy Hull used to record collaborations that sounded like reworkings of their respective catalogs, but they’ve finally articulated what this band is about.

title: How Am I Not Myself?
label: Danger Collective
description: On their second album, the cheerfully subversive L.A. art-punks critique societal norms as they revel in their own absurdity (and saxophone).

title: An Obelisk
label: Merge
description: Where Titus Andronicus once made great statements out of bloat, on their sixth album they do it with refreshing brevity.

title: 7 EP
label: Columbia
description: The songs on the debut EP from the viral rap and country star do not even come close to the pure magic of “Old Town Road.”

title: Turn Off the News (Build a Garden)
label: Fantasy
description: The son of Willie Nelson has led a charmed life, playing with Neil Young and inspiring Bradley Cooper in A Star Is Born. His own band’s throwback roots-rock toes the line of escapism.

title: Empathy EP
label: EMPIRE
description: The Chicago rapper and singer makes a name for herself with an airy, flexible voice that flows effortlessly between the sensuous and the sorrowful.

title: Big Dread Moon
label: Orindal
description: Claire Cronin’s latest record connects her lifelong love of horror movies to her simple, creaky songs.

title: Am I Who I Am
label: Trip
description: The Russian duo’s frenetic approach is more techno egg-and-spoon race than tech-house marathon, packed with improbable sounds, intriguing blind alleys, and eyebrow-raising quirks.

title: Endorphins
label: Black Butter
description: The rising London rapper flexes his versatility with a musically diverse set that feels more like a major studio debut than the mixtape it’s billed as.

title: Long Live Mexico
label: Young Stoner Life
description: The Atlanta rapper finally steps out of Young Thug’s shadow and showcases his own style and versatility.

title: A Bath Full of Ecstasy
label: Domino
description: The band’s seventh album is compulsively listenable, oddly moving, and stranger than it first appears.

title: Become Desert
label: Cantaloupe
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning composer’s latest installment in his Become trilogy is expansive and inviting. The piece explores resonance and the way sounds mutate, stick in our heads, or just disappear.

title: Nighttime Stories
label: Southern Lord
description: The instrumental metal quartet’s first album in six years grapples directly with loss and grief, channeling dueling guitars and pummeling rhythms into a dire, haunted sound.

title: The Complete Birth of the Cool
label: Blue Note
description: A modern-jazz touchstone that opened the door to the sleek introspection and sophisticated aplomb of 1950s cool jazz gets an exquisite and essential vinyl reissue.

title: Diaspora
label: Squaaash Club
description: GoldLink’s second album stretches far beyond his home in the DMV. It is a confluence of black music; hip-hop tracing its way back to the universal sounds of Africa.

title: Cages
label: New Age
description: The St. Louis metalpunks put their politics at the forefront of their music—except they’ve also got riffs, and they can write the hell out of a catchy, confrontational punk song.

title: Klaus Nomi
label: Real Gone
description: A reissue of the Downtown fixture’s 1981 debut album is a reminder that despite his striking look, campy repertoire, and operatic range, the onetime Bowie collaborator was no novelty act.

title: Madame X
label: Live Nation
description: Madonna’s 14th album feels stretched thin all over the globe, layered with an ambitious concept that ends up muddled and convoluted.

title: CHORDS
label: Subtext
description: On the follow-up to her 2017 album For organ and brass, the Swedish composer delves even deeper into microtonal interplay, balancing heady theoretical terrain with a rare emotional resonance.

title: Loom Dream
label: Whities
description: The resident DJ at the UK-based Freerotation festival releases a dreamy, bucolic ambient LP, full of lush textures and birdsong.

title: TEARS IN MY HENNESSY
label: Coming for Blood
description: The Bronx-born DJ melds genres at breakneck speed on a disconsolate and deeply personal breakup record.

title: Jinx
label: self-released
description: The New York City psych-rock quartet’s debut full-length beckons the listener with dreamy keyboards, twinkling guitar, and a recognizable buzz of stoic anxiety.

title: Years to Burn
label: Sub Pop
description: It took more than a decade to follow up In the Reins, but its successor reveals musicians who’ve learned to corral swarms of instruments and styles into a newly complex sound.

title: Back in Black
label: Leidseplein Presse B.V.
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the classic rock staple from a band who rebounded from tragedy to record one of the biggest albums ever made.

title: Black Star Dancing EP
label: Sour Mash
description: On his new EP, Noel Gallagher breaks free—a little—from his six-string to embrace the Big Beat of his youth.

title: The Age of Immunology
label: Fire
description: Drawing on its members’ diverse backgrounds and distinguished resumes—including work with Broadcast, Gruff Rhys, and Zongamin—the London band tilts its psychedelic pop toward a utopian future.

title: This Land Abounds With Life
label: self-released
description: Interpolating field recordings and birdsong, the Cuban-born jazz pianist's fourth album explores the sounds of his home country with warmth and fervor.

title: Sonic Youth: Battery Park, NYC: July 4, 2008
label: Matador
description: Three years before they split, at an Independence Day concert in a downtown park, the band tore through its earliest work with the polish of seasoned pros.

title: Derretirse EP
label: Dekmantel
description: Lush, heady, and shot through with an undercurrent of wistful contemplation, producer Brian Piñeyro’s “deep reggaetón” sound can’t be called lo-fi anymore.

title: Happiness Begins
label: Republic
description: The former teen heartthrobs’ first album in almost 10 years is by no means extraordinary, but it’s a respectable showing from a group that has long deserved more respect than they got.

title: Western Stars
label: Columbia
