description: Bruce Springsteen returns with elegiac and wise songwriting conjuring the golden expanse of the American West; it’s his best studio album in years.

title: Bob Dylan: Rolling Thunder Revue: The 1975 Live Recordings
label: Columbia
description: A mammoth, 14-CD box set released to accompany Martin Scorcese’s documentary captures the 1975 tour in all its ragged glory.

title: Shepherd in a Sheepskin Vest
label: Drag City
description: A peerless storyteller gazes deep into domestic life and offers a long, sun-warmed double album that is a highlight of his career.

title: SAVE ME EP
label: Epic
description: His latest EP proves he’s still a master of melancholic detail, but thematically and sonically, the Atlanta superstar has hit a wall.

title: Erotic Reruns
label: Yeasayer
description: A slight and unwaveringly safe 30 minutes, Yeasayer’s latest goes down easier than anything the band has ever done, while making less of an impression.

title: TIM
label: Universal Records
description: The Swedish EDM superstar’s posthumous final album purports to reveal Tim Bergling as he’s never been seen, but the scrum of co-writers and guest singers leaves more questions than answers.

title: Grass and Trees
label: Kranky
description: Jacob Long’s vaporous, lo-fi ambient tracks feel like snapshots of stillness made of moving parts.

title: Die a Legend
label: Columbia
description: Polo G blends pop and drill with ease and delivers a standout Chicago street rap debut that is meticulously crafted and honestly told.

title: Midnight
label: Saddle Creek
description: The Detroit indie rocker’s second album fluctuates between alt-rock and garage pop, turning up her amp and doubling down on her uncompromising style.

title: Islands
label: Keeled Scales
description: The singer-songwriter and pianist writes quietly epic songs about heartbreak, determination, and loneliness.

title: Black Mirror: Smithereens
label: Milan
description: The electronic musician and veteran soundtrack composer turns his interpretive abilities to a single episode of Charlie Brooker’s dystopian Netflix series, to subtle yet compelling effect.

title: Black Friday
label: Polyvinyl
description: Guitarist and bandleader Ellen Kempner’s third record breaks down the walls around her wiry, anxious riffs, opening space for levity and the thrill of new love.

title: Old Star
label: Peaceville
description: With their true Norwegian black metal days behind them and nothing left to prove, the longrunning duo trumpet their joyful debt to classic heavy metal.

title: Paradise
label: Company Records
description: The twin-brother jazz duo are experts at channeling the sounds of light and ease, and there’s something almost alchemical about their mutual precision.

title: Widow’s Weeds
label: New Machine
description: For a rock band who excels at high-intensity drama, their latest is set of mid-tempo snoozers that are over-refined, hermetically sealed, and safe.

title: Mirroring
label: Orchid Tapes
description: On her second album, singer and songwriter Johanne Swanson is wiser, steadier, and more willing to explore. Her music now feels like an expression of emotional epiphanies.

title: Sirens
label: Room40
description: The low-end mastermind behind the Bug and King Midas Sound turns his gut-rumbling frequencies and queasy atmospheres to the terrors of new parenthood.

title: Never Say Goodbye
label: Emperor Jones
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the lo-fi acoustic recordings of Roky Erickson, a rare glimpse at his stark and fragile songwriting.

title: Personal Best / Captain My Captain / Choices, Chances, Changes: Singles & Comptracks 1994-2000
label: Jealous Butcher
description: A new reissue collects the work of the pioneering icons of queer punk, whose uncompromising approach and knowing intimacies made them pre-Tumblr beacons of community.

title: Pale Bloom
label: W.25TH
description: The Canadian composer turns from electroacoustic minimalism to contemplative, deeply focused compositions for piano, organ, voice, and strings.

title: Weeping Choir
label: Relapse
description: On their Relapse debut, the infernal Full of Hell crack apart metal genres like oracle bones.

title: Spiritual 2
label: Beyond Beyond is Beyond
description: The Seoul duo taps into devotional music’s focused intensity in trance-inducing pieces that draw on new age, krautrock, and folk.

title: What the Brokenhearted Do...
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The comedian and musician brings his dry absurdity and taste for 1970s singer-songwriters to a novel venture: a fake breakup album.

title: Originals
label: Warner Bros.
description: Hearing Prince sing these songs that he gave to other performers brings you close to the pulse of his artistry: transgressive, funky, sexy, a testament to his genius even in the form of demos.

title: Lust for Youth
label: Sacred Bones
description: Hannes Norrvide's long-running coldwave synth project breaks into the greener pastures of Depeche Mode-style new wave.

title: Venq Tolep
label: Pampa
description: The German producer offers his prettiest, silkiest, and most poignant minimal electronic music ever.

title: Out of Sight
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Neither rigidly authentic nor conspicuously modern, the North Carolina folk scholar honors the past through transformation rather than reinvention.

title: Leak 04-13 (Bait Ones)
label: XL
description: The decade’s most tantalizing pop enigma officially releases a trove of unfinished material that was originally leaked online six years ago.

title: April is the Cruellest Month
label: Blank Forms
description: Unreleased at the time, the Japanese guitarist's elemental free jazz opus provides the missing link between Albert Ayler, Merzbow, and Acid Mothers Temple.

title: Mandy & the Jungle
label: Monster Boy
description: The omnivorous Nigerian rapper-singer makes smoothly effortless genre hybrids that feel like everywhere and nowhere all at once.

title: Introducing Juan Pablo
label: Captured Tracks
description: The Uruguayan-American singer-songwriter's latest is a charmingly loose grab bag, dotted with field recordings and snippets of sampled conversation.

title: She Is Coming EP
label: RCA
description: The first EP of a forthcoming trilogy from the pop icon is all over the place. It misuses her talents and makes for a largely unrewarding listen.

title: solipsisters
label: Run for Cover
description: The Australian bedroom-pop artist’s third album demonstrates that her attention to how her songs start, end, and connect has never been keener or better controlled.

title: Hot Spring
label: Run for Cover
description: The more relaxed, country-adjacent follow-up to 2017’s Enjoy the Great Outdoors pairs pastoral modes with surreal meditations on a warming world.

title: The Peyote Dance
label: Bella Union
description: Over field recordings sourced from the Mexico of Antonin Artaud’s travels, the New York singer gives voice to the French poet’s hallucinogenic visions.

title: In the West
label: Comedy Minus One
description: Though the Seattle band would produce more focused efforts, In the West is a fascinating document of nascent indie rock that sounds revelatory 25 years later.

title: ZUU
label: Loma Vista
description: The South Florida rapper puts on for his city and delivers the best, most dynamic, and altogether hardest album of his career.

title: Where Future Unfolds
label: International Anthem
description: The Chicago-based improvisational artist layers politically charged sound collages over drum machines and a children’s choir. The result is uplifting activist jazz for tumultuous times.

title: Pianoworks
label: Temporary Residence
description: Matthew Cooper's second solo piano record in 15 years glows with a childlike wonder underscored by mature regret.

title: Rocketman (Music From the Motion Picture)
label: Interscope
description: The music from Elton John’s life sinks into the uncanny valley with a studio band, a substitute singer, and a silver-screen production that misses the finer points of the legendary performer’s career.

title: Run Around the Sun
label: Merge
description: The Scotland-based duo delight in controlled chaos, interweaving arguments and anxieties with their most exuberant work to date.

title: Terror Twilight
label: Matador
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Pavement’s divisive final album, full of clamor and clarity that presaged the end of the underground.

title: Dispassionate EP
label: Nettwerk
description: The California surf-garage rockers extend their recent series of EPs, and succumb to their own sense of anhedonia.

title: Water Memory / Mount Vision
label: Rvng Intl.
description: The L.A.-based Sprague steps away from her indie pop trio Florist for rippling, patient, and redemptive ambient drone works for modular synthesizers.

title: From Here to Eternity
label: Past Inside the Present
description: The Montreal ambient musician’s albums all resemble each other in their broad strokes and abiding stillness. They are beautiful, terrifying, and bittersweet all at once.

title: Boat
label: Heavenly
description: The Dutch quartet undercut their perky, grunge-lite melodies with just the right amount of pop-fuzz aggression.

title: Ignorance Is Bliss
label: Boy Better Know
description: Three years after he galvanized a new class of grime MCs, the UK rapper tries to meet the high bar he set for himself.

title: Swim Team EP
label: Father/Daughter
description: The Congolese American songwriter and guitarist’s debut EP winds in circles, tracing vast spaces that couch thorny emotional quagmires.

title: Rainford
label: On-U Sound
description: After years spent trading on a bulletproof back catalog and eccentric persona, the Jamaican titan teams up with UK dub heavyweight Adrian Sherwood for a welcome return to form.

title: REMEMBER THE FUTURE
label: To whom it may concern.
description: On the follow-up to her debut solo album, the former iamamiwhoami member tilts her off-kilter electro pop toward compellingly dystopian visions.

title: 43VA HEARTLESS
label: N-Less
description: The consistent Memphis rapper continues his workmanlike grind to the top.

title: Falaw
label: Sahel Sounds
description: The Malian producer employs ngoni and other regional sounds in hip-hop-inspired fusions that, at their best, suggest a West African beat tape.

title: Apollo XXI
label: 3qtr
description: The singer and guitarist’s debut solo album offers an introspective blend of R&B, hip-hop, & lo-fi pop but feels reluctant to claim the spotlight.

title: Escape From New York
label: Columbia
description: On their first album as a collective, Beast Coast attempt to move beyond the boom-bap revivalism that made them famous.

title: Full Upon Her Burning Lips
label: Sargent House
description: The minimalist drone-riff masters pare away excess and focus on the seismic repetition that made their best work so resonant, creating a new peak in their long discography.

title: Atlanta Millionaires Club
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The 21-year-old singer-songwriter’s third album is serene folk-pop with a mellow soul tinge and the melancholy clarity of someone twice her age.

title: i'll show you stronger
label: Rhyme & Reason
description: The Brooklyn-based musician’s long-percolating debut is a collection of small dream-pop ditties that only feel cheery on the outside.

title: Destroyer
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Reinvigorated with a whole host of new members, the metal outfit prove there's plenty of life left in their road-trip rock.

title: Zoospa
label: Innovative Leisure
description: The first collaborative full-length by producers Machinedrum and Jimmy Edgar bounces across genres and eras, but the real magic comes from the guest vocalists.

title: Support Alien Invasion
label: Cómeme
description: The Chilean-German producer’s steely, slinky polyrhythms are a repudiation of borders and a celebration of the freedom of movement.

title: Reward
label: Mexican Summer
description: On her fifth album, the Welsh musician is at her best. The more elaborate and eccentric her music becomes, the more she sounds like herself.

title: Act Surprised
label: Dangerbird
description: Where 2013’s cautious Defend Yourself attempted a belated recovery from a disappointing major-label debut, the indie-rock icons’ latest sounds like the work of a band refreshingly free of baggage.

title: Paradox
label: Profound Lore
description: The cult death metal act returns with a fresh blast of hellish air, full of joyously absurd keyboards, hyper-technical guitars, and apocalyptic sci-fi visions.

title: Forever Breathes the Lonely Word
label: Creation
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the misanthropic pop perfection of the indie British band’s sixth and best album.

title: Diviner
label: Domino
description: The former Wild Beasts singer embarks on a new direction on his soul-searching solo debut, stripping back his songwriting to a reverent hush.

title: Dozakh: All Lovers Hell
label: YEAR0001
description: The debut album from the Iranian-Swedish artist offers a fascinatingly dark take on romantic love, filled with images of violence and devastation.

title: California Son
label: BMG
description: Morrissey and some (barely audible) high-profile guests rework 12 of his favorite ’60s and ’70s songs by American artists to mixed results.

title: Brown Rice
label: Verve
description: Reissued on vinyl some 40 years after its initial release, Don Cherry’s sprawling, free, ecstatic masterwork defined what came to be known as “world” music.

title: We Get By
label: Anti-
description: The legendary singer has lost little expressiveness with age, but these songs are about the small, quiet spaces where she can catch her breath and steel her nerves.

title: Amyl and the Sniffers
label: ATO
description: The Aussie rockers’ unabashed fetishization of 1970s staples like punk, glam, and their country’s sharpie scene only helps fuel the invigorating rush of their music.

title: Flamagra
label: Warp
description: On Steven Ellison’s sixth album, his sweeping jazz-funk feels limitless. It sounds more like a sketchbook with FlyLo crafting each minute with great care and technical dexterity.

title: 4REAL 4REAL
label: Def Jam
description: YG pays heartfelt tribute to the late Nipsey Hussle on his latest while still reserving plenty of vitriol for his favorite targets: broke dudes, snitches, broke dudes who also snitch.

title: STFU II EP
label: Glydezone
description: Picking up where his DJ-Kicks mix left off, the L.A. funk auteur’s newest release explores peace and love through body-rock.

title: Ecstatic Computation
label: Editions Mego
description: The Italian synthesizer composer explores new dimensions of her algorithmic, arpeggiated sound, playing with tempo, duration, and pacing to toy with listeners’ sense of perception.

title: Fever
label: 1501 Certified
description: Megan Thee Stallion’s debut is steeped in sex, pimpin, and power; it sounds like a once and future Houston rap classic.

title: We Fall
label: The Sound of Sinners
description: On her debut solo album, the Breeders’ original bassist blends her signature instrument with minimalist electronics and rippling pools of piano, Mellotron, and acoustic guitar.

title: Radiant Dawn
label: Last Gang
description: Crosswiring ’80s-Springsteen valor with contemporaneous synth pop, the second album from Dan Boeckner’s disco power trio channels the crushing fear of imminent collapse.

title: A Fine Mess EP
label: Matador
description: Culled from last year’s Marauder sessions with Dave Fridmann, there’s still a sense that the production actively tries to disrupt what Interpol does well.

title: Injury Reserve
label: Loma Vista
description: The oddball Phoenix rap trio traffic in wild, boundary-pushing production and playfully anarchic bars.

title: Father of Asahd
label: We the Best
description: DJ Khaled has ranged from summertime hitmaker to self-help guru, and neither are all that interesting on his latest guest-filled album. There are plenty of voices but no clear message or intention.

title: Galazy EP
label: Young Ethics
description: On the first release on his new label Young Ethics, the Swedish producer steps outside his hazy comfort zone.

title: 13th Floor
label: self-released
description: With hard-nosed bars and ominous, bass-heavy beats, the Canadian rapper’s debut album is her most cohesive and narratively ambitious effort to date.

title: I Am the Last of That Green and Warm-Hued World
label: Hausu Mountain
description: Within an album that often sounds like an alien world, small moments of familiarity become breadcrumbs leading to a shared musicology.

title: Nothing Great About Britain
label: True Panther
description: The Bajan-British rapper’s debut tackles the UK’s pressing crises—a looming Brexit, class hostility, widening poverty—with great jokes and writerly candor.

title: Origin EP
label: Warp
description: The New York pianist’s stripped-back companion piece to her electronic-tinged 2018 album Ultraviolet is an engrossing ode to the act of creation.

title: Pacific Breeze: Japanese City Pop, AOR & Boogie 1976-1986
label: Light in the Attic
description: This compilation of extra smooth, funky, and sometimes very odd songs from the heydey of Japan’s technological boom is a broad yet nuanced introduction to the genre of city pop.

title: IGOR
label: Columbia
description: Tyler, the Creator’s sixth album is impressionistic and emotionally charged, the result of an auteur refining his style and baring more of his soul than ever before.

title: Living Theatre
label: Trouble in Mind
description: The Brooklyn group’s second album frames heavy questions in lovely, deceptively serene psych rock.

title: Spice
label: Virgin
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the sleek pop, British nationalism, and commercial girl power of the Spice Girls’ debut.

title: Natty Light
label: JABS
description: This collection of 7"s and compilation tracks documents the band’s formative years, in which frenzied hardcore and proto-screamo was rapidly churning toward more radical strains of noise.

title: Le personnage principal est un peuple isolé
label: Stroom
description: STROOM, a Belgian label whose releases are not so much reissues as alternate histories of avant-garde pop, surveys the dreamlike soundscapes of a fringe figure from the 1980s.

title: Spirit
label: Loma Vista
description: Playing a baby grand piano, Mike Milosh’s eight-song album reflects a sense of ritualistic quiet; it’s intimate without being heavy-handed.

title: The Movie
label: Dog Knights
description: The Gothenburg emo band specialize in commiseration rock, crafting combustible rallying cries for the overwhelmed and underemployed.

title: Matchy Matchy
label: Fika
description: With their first album in six years, New York City indie-pop duo the Ballet question the complexities of modern queer life but offer no easy answers.

title: Dedicated
label: School Boy
description: On her fourth album, the Canadian pop star is doing what she does best, calibrating lovesick or lovelorn synthpop that’s neither too hot nor too cold—and sometimes, regrettably, only lukewarm.

title: The Best of Luck Club
label: Dead Oceans
description: The Australian pop-punk musician’s second album is a welcome and wide-open look at mid-twenties inertia and queer romance.

title: Ryan Pollie
label: Anti-
description: The L.A.-based singer-songwriter recorded the first album under his own name from the trenches of chemotherapy and a breakup, but the result is an exercise in gentle vulnerability and winsome grace.

title: Sombrou Dúvida
label: OAR
description: The Brazilian psych band transition from the oft-playful homage and stage-ready jams of previous releases to a serious attempt at tight, kaleidoscopic grooves.

title: Water
label: Fire Talk
description: The Chicago indie-rock trio scrape away 90 percent of what goes into a guitar album and come away with something effortless and uncomplicated.

title: Beauty Marks
label: Beauty Marks
description: The singer’s seventh album moves between frothy pop-R&B and stale empowerment anthems that leave her talents largely underused.

title: Sings Music for Daydreaming
label: Salinas
description: Sam Cook-Parrott returns to his beginnings as a solo artist, an experiment that yields playful piano compositions and introspective lyricism.

title: I Am Easy to Find
label: 4AD
description: With a cast of female vocalists guiding and redirecting the songs, the National’s eighth album is their largest, longest, and most daring.

label: Goner
description: The Memphis post-punk band’s third album wages guerrilla warfare against the patriarchal surveillance state.

title: Shea Butter Baby
label: Dreamville
description: The debut album from the neo-soul singer-songwriter is driven by warm funk and soul and has the healing familiarity of hanging out on the couch commiserating with a best friend.

title: LEGACY! LEGACY!
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The Chicago artist marries political commentary with deep introspection, resulting in a richly composed R&B album about the echoes of the past and the promise of the future.

title: Divided by Darkness
label: 20 Buck Spin
description: Led by young oracle Nate Garrett, the second album from the Arizona heavy metal band carries the torch of their forebears and revives the genre with impressive songwriting and ambition.

title: Hexhammaren
label: Southern Lord
description: Eighteen years into its existence, the Swedish band continues to find ways to make a familiar fusion of melodic death metal, crust punk, and d-beat sound fresh.

title: Age Hasn’t Spoiled You
label: Carpark
description: On their first new album in eight years, the Toronto punk band tear down everything they’ve ever known about making music and rebuild themselves for the better.

title: PROTO
label: 4AD
description: Created with a choral ensemble and a nascent AI, the Berlin-based electronic musician’s third album is a meditation on community, technology, and the future of, and beyond, the human species.

title: LOVE&JETT
label: Third Man
description: On their 13th album, the Japanese rock’n’rollers reaffirm what they do best: making the once-rebellious sounds of surf, rockabilly, and CBGB punk seem dangerous again.

title: Young Enough
label: Barsuk
description: The Brooklyn band’s second record is bigger and darker, amplifying their ’80s new-wave sparkle into ecstatic triumph.

title: Wheeltappers and Shunters
label: Domino
description: The art-punk eccentrics’ first album in six years is a woozy celebration of Britain’s sleazy past, and it sounds like nobody other than Clinic.

title: Phantom Forest
label: self-released
description: The ever-ambitious Toronto composer tackles big themes on her environmentally minded song cycle, but keeps things refreshingly immediate and small-scale.

title: Stolen Youth
label: Blacksmith
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Mac Miller and Vince Staples’ 2013 mixtape, a fledgling but important document of freeform creativity.

title: DOLO 4
label: Future Times
description: The Washington D.C. producer’s drum tracks are bold, burly numbers that move with abandon. Even without melodies, no two sound remotely alike.

title: are SING SINCK, SING
label: Constellation
description: This joint project from Efrim Manuel Menuck and Kevin Doria has an overwhelming radiance to match Menuck's work in Godspeed You! Black Emperor.

title: Failed Entertainment
label: Run for Cover
description: The O.C. hardcore band level up their sound on their second album but remain gruff, guttural, and ferocious.

title: Eat My Pussy Again
label: Machine Entertainment Group
description: On the sequel to last year’s Eat My Pussy, the Chicago rapper’s songwriting is at times more brazen and at others more introspective.

title: Here Comes the Cowboy
label: Mac’s Record Label
description: The latest from the indie rock rapscallion is an often pretty, occasionally frustrating record that was recorded quickly, but still sounds labored over.

title: Emerald Valley
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: The second album from Corin Tucker and Peter Buck’s alt-rock supergroup can’t match the urgency of pre-apocalyptic protest.

title: Anoyo
label: Kranky
description: The follow-up to last year’s Konoyo—recorded, like its predecessor, with a Japanese gagaku ensemble—functions as a counterbalance to that album: a kind of photo negative, more subdued but no less overwhelming.

title: A Thousand Leaves
label: Geffen
description: After a string of surprisingly and contentiously accessible albums, SY attempted to balance their pop curiosity with its experimental instincts.

title: EVOL
label: SST
description: The core elements of Sonic Youth were still scattered all over their 1986 album, but its dark and sordid sound brilliantly captured the essence of an “underground” band coming to life.

title: Experimental Jet Set, Trash and No Star
label: Geffen
description: Somewhere between a sorta-pop stab and pointedly hook-free, SY’s eighth album is ambivalent and shaggy by design.

title: Washing Machine
label: Geffen
description: SY’s ninth record marked a new era for the band. While they didn’t leave the freaky stuff behind entirely, they started serving it up with a spoonful of sugar.

title: Sister
label: SST
description: At turns paranoid and explosive, Sister marks a climactic finish to the early albums that carved the New York band’s sound into punk and alternative culture.

title: The Dots
label: Marathon Artists
description: The English six-piece’s debut is a high-wire act combining jazz fusion, disco rhythms, and high-gloss art rock.

title: Sli’merre
label: Paradise East
description: On one of the best rapper/producer collaborations of the year, the Atlanta MC remains a perfect fit for Pi’erre Bourne’s weird and heavy beats.

title: there is no Other
label: Nonesuch
description: The singer and multi-instrumentalist joins jazz musician Francesco Turrisi for a thoughtful and ambitious album that spans opera, Appalachian bluegrass, gospel, and traditional Italian music.

title: KOD
label: TF
description: The BandGang crew is at the center of Detroit’s rap renaissance, and Lonnie Bands’ latest is a great showcase of its sound and energy.

title: Poltergeist Slim
label: Lost Appeal
description: The Baltimore rapper switches between singing, rapping, mumbling until there's almost no difference between the words and the beats.

title: Voicemails
label: Winter's Diary
description: The Chicago singer/rapper known for her diaristic, relationship-dissecting R&B builds her new mixtape around inherently private and frequently drama-filled voice messages.

title: Enderness
label: Fat Possum
description: On his first album in eight years, the Alabama singer-songwriter turns from folk music to synths, drum machines, and internet speak, but the sorrow at the heart of his music is timeless.

title: YU
label: Caroline International
description: The smoky-voiced R&B multi-instrumentalist charts the ups and downs of a relationship with the help of guests like Jay Electronica and Floating Points.

title: Active Listening: Night on Earth
label: Get Better
description: The Philadelphia quartet’s full-length debut showcases their defiant brand of noise-pop, a big rainbow of chaos.

title: U.F.O.F.
label: 4AD
description: The third album from the Brooklyn quartet is an intimate and surreal experience, a true masterpiece of folk music from a band working together at the highest level.

title: Useless Coordinates
label: Captured Tracks
description: The ferocious Leeds trio treat post-punk like a game of Tetris, joyfully flipping and rearranging the elements into new patterns.

title: This Mess Is a Place
label: Sub Pop
description: The Seattle band’s fourth record, their first for Sub Pop, is forward-thinking pop-punk that successfully—albeit narrowly—manages to dodge the obvious pitfalls.

title: Your Need
label: 2MR
description: Crafted in tandem with the Gost Zvuk affiliate Flaty, the Moscow producer’s second album balances streamlined electro pop with a hint of rave mayhem.

title: Selected Ambient Works Volume II
label: Warp
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit an album that changed ambient music forever.

title: KingMaker
label: Blue Note
description: The 23-year-old vibraphonist shines on his debut album with an approach that feels sly and mysterious; he also proves himself a sharp bandleader attuned to the importance of group dynamics.

title: Anger Management
label: Atlantic
description: Just 18 minutes with Kenny Beats shows Rico Nasty evolving. She remains one of the heaviest hitters in the no-rules arena of rap.

title: Night Pass
label: Infinite Companion
description: After being dropped from their label, the Portland duo flout despair with a wall of nostalgic, over-the-top sound.

title: Covered N Blood
label: Glizzy Gang
description: As with all of his best work, the D.C. rapper’s latest finds him grappling with trauma, haunted by the specter of death at every turn.

title: Violet Street
label: Loma Vista
description: The L.A. band has long carried the flag for a particular strain of SoCal indie, but the follow-up to 2016’s fashionably yearning Sunlit Youth sounds both more personal and more timeless.

title: Scatter the Rats
label: Blackheart
description: The grunge act's first LP in 20 years fails to summon the revolutionary fire that made them such a force of nature in the mid-'90s.

title: Father of the Bride
label: Columbia
description: Vampire Weekend return with a shaggy, sprawling double album all about rebirth, contentment, and the reclamation of light.

title: Green and Gray
label: Exploding in Sound
description: The seventh album from the Boston noise-rock band revels in a heightened level of studio ambition without losing its snarling ferocity.

title: Preacher to the Streets
label: Sick Wid It
description: The Sacramento rapper spends most of his second album conscience-stricken, trying to explain the difference between being immoral and being corrupted.

title: Run Fast Sleep Naked
label: Downtown
description: The second album from the musician formerly known as Chet Faker is at once overstuffed and underwhelming.

title: Mettavolution
label: ATO
description: The Mexican duo’s first album in five years applies their customary virtuoso fusion of classical guitar and contemporary rock to six short originals and a 19-minute cover of Pink Floyd’s “Echoes.”

title: ARIZONA BABY
label: Question Everything
description: The BROCKHAMPTON star’s latest solo album is an often powerful document by a queer artist who has weathered life’s bruises.

title: Music for Donuts EP
label: Thrilling Living
description: The Mississippi punk four-piece celebrate slugs, butter, lard, chewing gum—the important things.

title: LuvHz EP
label: Luminelle
description: The Mexican American electro-pop artist’s debut EP, produced with Panda Bear collaborator Rusty Santos, is a restless patchwork of genre-smashing sounds.

title: Take Off Mode
label: Planet Mu
description: As he returns to the intricate polyrhythms and hypnotic vocal chops of footwork, the Chicago producer’s approach remains almost single-minded in its focus.

title: Oh My God
label: Dead Oceans
description: Morby's spare fifth solo album conjures memories of gospel-phase Dylan.

title: What Life
label: Tiny Engines
description: The Oakland quintet’s debut album is a spirited indie-emo blend driven by intricate underlying themes, channeling a slew of influences even as it exists in a space of its own.

title: Organism EP
label: Majia
description: The Chicago producer plays with oceanic imagery and a collage-like swirl of influences on a four-track EP that spills over the limits of club music’s conventions.

title: In League With Dragons
label: Merge
description: John Darnielle explores the humanity of wizards, sports legends, Ozzy Osbourne, and other folk heroes and beacons of hope.

title: CrasH Talk
label: Top Dawg
description: The L.A. rapper’s latest is comforting if not entirely exciting. It finds Q and host of guests in a good place with nothing to prove.

title: You Can't Sit With Us
label: self-released
description: On their first project in five years, Saba's crew sounds like a bunch of friends at the lunch table trying to out-rap each other for fun.

title: For the Throne (Music Inspired by the HBO Series Game of Thrones)
label: Columbia
description: Instead of nerding out or having any kind of fun, a host of pop stars turn in a dour, stone-faced compilation of songs inspired by the ubiquitous fantasy saga.

title: Itekoma Hits
label: Damnably
description: The Kyoto punk quartet unleashes a tornado of defiance at the prospect of romance, monotonous office work, and people who feel entitled to women’s time.

title: Love + Fear
label: Atlantic
description: Marina Diamandis’ first album since shedding her “Marina and the Diamonds” identity slides from affecting poetry to cold calculation.

title: I Need a New War
label: Partisan
description: The Hold Steady frontman's solo work continues its twilit exploration of frail hopes, wasted lives, and quiet battles against despair.

title: The Jewel in the Lotus
label: Universal Records
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a confluence of jazz’s past and present, an unsung modernist classic from 1974.

title: The Secret of Letting Go
label: Cooking Vinyl
description: The veteran trip-hoppers once stood out by virtue of their idiosyncratic sound, but two decades later, they’ve resorted to playing things frustratingly straight.

title: Exit
label: Sleeping Giant Glossolalia
description: Always one for gender subversion, the Toronto songwriter invites a cast of men to sing her songs, resulting in some of the project’s most deviously playful music ever.

title: Seeing Other People
label: ‎Jagjaguwar‎
description: The troubled outfit's latest album bitterly recounts the Decline of Foxygen.

title: Fly Times, Vol. 1: The Good Fly Young
label: Atlantic
description: One of the most quietly influential rappers of the last ten years maintains cruising altitude.

title: Designer
label: 4AD
description: The third album from the impressionistic New Zealand singer-songwriter eludes easy classification, which makes her delicately built and beautifully rendered songs all the more alluring.

title: Blood
label: Columbia
description: Featuring collaborations with Skrillex and Jamie xx, the West Coast transplant’s debut album flips the chamber-folk cello of her debut EP into a contemporary, decidedly Los Angeles hybrid sound.

title: Fishing for Fishies
label: ATO
description: The idiosyncratic Australian band’s most streamlined album to date is risky only in that it is their first to be downright boring.

title: Truck Music
label: self-released
description: Christopher Taylor’s genre-colliding mutant pop proves everything can fit if you don’t give it enough time to sound wrong.

title: 2nd
label: Dots Per Inch
description: The Queens-based songwriter offers nervy lo-fi synth pop that buzzes with everyday anxiety.

title: A Quiet Farwell, Twenty Sixteen to Twenty Eighteen
label: Grand Closing
description: The New York producer’s ambitious album is a dark, surreal, jazzy collage about resistance and hope.

title: Life Metal
label: Southern Lord
description: The titanic drone metal duo returns with Steve Albini for an enormous, meticulous, back-to-basics album that shows just how compelling those basics can be.

title: Jade Bird
label: Glassnote
description: The British singer-songwriter’s debut fortifies her early promise as a confident young voice of country-charred rock

title: Stockholm Marathon
label: Studio Barnhus
description: The Swedish producer’s second full-length album is streaked with bright, bold melodies yet marked with a lightness of touch that’s unusual in dance music.

title: Internet Arms
label: Polyvinyl
description: On his third release as the genre-bending alter ego Diane Coffee, Shaun Fleming explores the trap of online intimacy.

title: Wooh Dang
label: Superpuma
description: The hermetic Swedish bedroom-pop auteur spins out songs of electric uplift and dreamy solitude on his first international release.

title: Still Summer in the Projects
label: Alamo
description: The incarcerated Watts rapper’s latest release, a collaboration with Mustard, is exultant and Dionysian.

title: Absolute Zero
label: Thirty Tigers
description: Jazz fusion, chamber pop, modern classical—if your awareness of Hornsby stops at the lite-FM radio dial, prepare to be disoriented.

title: Family Not a Group
label: Def Jam
description: The Bay Area rap crew’s collaboration with Hit-Boy catches them in a moment of furious flux.

title: I Love You. It’s a Fever Dream.
label: Rivers/Birds
description: As he explores the banalities and oddities of tour, Kristian Matsson seeks answers to a bigger question: How best should he move through the landscape of his life?

title: Industrial Accident: The Story of Wax Trax! Records
label: Wax Trax!
description: The soundtrack to a documentary about the flagship indie label features early material from Ministry, My Life With the Thrill Kill Kult, and other industrial icons.

title: Akron, Ohio
label: Tee Pee
description: The Black Keys’ Patrick Carney and longtime indie-rock journeyman John Petkovic team up on a graceless, unsubtle pastiche of rock’n’roll indulgence.

title: Raw Honey
label: Mexican Summer
description: L.A.-based auteur Michael Collins crafts a pristine portrait of early-’70s AM radio by taking inspiration not only from the period’s definitive artists, but its discarded pop detritus, too.

title: Cuz I Love You
label: Nice Life
description: The shiny soul-pop of Lizzo’s major label debut is something of a thesis on internalized and externalized confidence—so much so that the music can feel like a means to a greater end.

title: Covert Contracts
label: Get Better
description: On their debut album, the anarchic Philly hardcore trio muster a raw, thrilling assault against complacency.

title: Floral Shoppe
label: Beer On The Rug
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the banal ennui of vaporwave with its pioneering document from 2011.

title: Intellexual
label: Fantasy
description: The Social Experiment members reintroduce themselves as earnest singer-songwriters, but their post-genre mashup production produces more vibes than actual songs.

title: A Black Market Album
label: Sunthings
description: The Belgian beatmaker ups his game, roping in guest vocalists Siifu, Spote Breeze, and Mamoyo on a breezy, 22-minute album that, at its best, recalls golden-age Slum Village.

title: Orange
label: New Amsterdam
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning composer returns with a wild and free-ranging collection of chamber pieces.

title: ~~~ EP
label: Leaving
description: The Los Angeles-based ambient musician’s EP is restful and restorative, using lo-fi tones and textures to create a work that subtly transcends.

title: Homecoming: The Live Album
label: Parkwood
description: Beyoncé’s historic Coachella set is preserved as a stunning live album that captures an artist at her peak, flexing her catalog and shining a light on the genius of black artists that came before her.

title: No Dados
label: Suah Sounds
description: The North Carolinian singer comes roaring back from multiple strokes to deliver a raw and thrilling solo debut.

title: Utopía
label: Sony Latin
description: The Dominican bachata king follows his chart-topping Golden with a celebration of the genre's rich history, lifting up his forebears and revealing his musical DNA.

title: Grim Town
label: Rough Trade
description: On her second album, the Northern Irish musician graduates from lonesome singer-songwriter to bold art-pop auteur; her growing confidence translates to emotionally probing songs of startling candor.

title: High Highs to Low Lows
label: Keep It On the Lolo
description: Don’t be fooled by the of-the-moment pop sound: The 24-year-old singer’s debut album is the showcase for a refreshingly original perspective.

title: Invitation
label: Western Vinyl
description: Three albums in, the Oregon-based multi-instrumentalist still sounds as though she’s composing music en plein air.

title: Laughing Matter
label: Drag City
description: As they pare away at their sound, Wand move further away from psych-rock and closer to true psychedelia.

title: Where Polly People Go to Read
label: AWAL
description: The debut from the it-boy bedroom pop auteur manages to feel both excitingly personal and a bit disingenuous.

title: Let’s Try the After Vol. 2 EP
label: Arts & Crafts
description: On the second half of their paired EPs, the Toronto collective settles into comfortable territory that soon proves stale.

title: I Must Be the Devil
label: Bel-Air Glamour Records
description: The former múm frontwoman steps out with a set of airy, orchestral folk that resembles early Kate Bush or Joanna Newsom.

title: Dogrel
label: Partisan
description: The steely Dublin post-punk band infuse the bitterness and rage of The Fall with punch-drunk romanticism.

title: Rose Gold
label: Pretty Wavy
description: With low-stakes dance-pop that simmers just beneath the surface, the artist formerly known as Kitty Pryde attempts to transcend her internet bubble.

title: LSD
label: Columbia
description: Diplo, Sia, and Labrinth combine forces for an album of truly forgettable pop music that is too tired to be wired.

title: Song Feel
label: Night Slugs
description: Nearly a decade after helping revolutionize the sound of UK bass, the veteran Night Slugs producer struggles to maintain the radicalism of his early music on his debut album.

title: Imperial Flood
label: Different Circles
description: A pioneer of what he once termed “weightless” bass music moves toward the outer fringes of club aesthetics on an album imbued with the apocalyptic overtones of sci-fi and speculative fiction.

title: WARMER
label: dBpm
description: Recorded at the same time as last year’s WARM, the companion album showcases Tweedy’s aged songwriting that continues to be humble and revealing.

title: Everybody Split
label: Hobbies Galore
description: The unassuming Melbourne five-piece build garage-jangle guitars and blunt-edged harmonies into strangely hypnotic arrangements that feel simultaneously long and short.

title: Sulphur English
label: Relapse
description: The Richmond metal quintet’s fourth album is its most intense and most rewarding: a virtual symphony of pummeling, dissonant riffs sculpted with unrelenting precision.

title: MAP OF THE SOUL : PERSONA
label: BigHit Entertainment
description: The biggest K-pop group in the world try to move their sound forward but spend too much time leaning on their past.

title: All Time Present
label: No Quarter
description: Accompanied by a handful of his Solar Motel Band collaborators, the Philadelphia guitarist seeks the third path between classic-rock peaks and floating experimentalism.

title: Mandatory Reality
label: Eremite
description: The Chicago bassist and guimbri player turns in a minimalist mountain of an album, one whose slow pace and gradual changes prove unusually mesmerizing, even sublime.

title: Who Is Jill Scott?: Words and Sounds, Vol. 1
label: Hidden Beach
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the 2000 debut of Jill Scott, a neo-soul chronicle that brought love and sex to the everywoman.

title: Personal Rock
label: Faitiche
description: Twenty years ago, the German electronic musician Jan Jelinek’s tools were rustier, his loops lumpier, yet his vision for a transcendent music of digital failure was very much intact.

title: Only You Can See It
label: Carpark
description: The Brooklyn-based pop polymath writes, performs, records, mixes, and engineers her most ambitious and electrifying collection of songs to date.

title: Essentials
label: Fire Talk
description: The Brooklyn post-punk trio’s debut full-length reveals an instinct for scrappy, empathetic songwriting.

title: El Chan
label: Deutsche Grammophon
description: Indie rock’s preeminent classical composer offers a selection of piano pieces from minimal, to rousing, to a heroic concerto for two pianos backed by a full orchestra.

title: Ventura
label: 12 Tone
description: After the hard left turn of Oxnard, Paak sinks back into the bubbly smooth grooves that got him noticed.

title: Brutalism
label: Anti-
description: The latest album from the Drums—now just frontman Jonny Pierce—is his most honest and most unvarnished.

title: No Geography
label: Astralwerks
description: Blending psychedelic sensory overload with riotous club bangers, the shape-shifting electronic duo’s ninth album is their most entertaining in years.

title: Ribbons
label: Warp
description: After drifting into ambient drone on his last album, Stephen Wilkins returns to his chill, bucolic stomping grounds.

title: Long Story Short
label: Below System Records
description: With a nonchalant flow, Eto paints a grim and familiar world where only survival-of-the-fittest tactics prevail alongside sumptuous production from Superior.

title: Kill This Love EP
label: YG
description: The K-pop girl group’s enjoyable but weirdly dated EP offers a mishmash of EDM styles ahead of their big Coachella debut.

title: What a Boost
label: Memphis Industries
description: Like a half-forgotten dream, the English singer-songwriter’s combination of minimalist blues and free-floating jazz feels just out of reach.

title: Even in the Tremor
label: Ba Da Bing Records
description: The Brooklyn singer-songwriter’s third album takes a microscope to the messy business of being human, finding revelatory moments of empathy in the smallest everyday details.

title: Signals Bulletin
label: Faitiche
description: The German experimental musician teams up with a Japanese organist prone to taping down the keys of his instrument; together, they conjure massive, buzzing slabs of drone.

title: Free Spirit
label: Right Hand Music Group
description: The second album from the historically inoffensive singer is another genreless collection of safe choices for a pop star in the making.

title: Saturday the 14th EP

title: Haunted Items
label: Sub Pop

title: We Need to Talk

title: Hiding Places

title: The Slider
label: Spirit Records

title: Deserted
label: Bloodshot

title: Thalassa
label: Sargent House

title: Autoclave

title: Triad
label: Presto!?

title: Morbid Stuff

title: In the Shape of a Storm

title: Supermarket

title: Lifelike
label: Trouble in Mind

title: Tuez-Les Tous

title: Guns

title: Mise En Abyme

title: Ilana (The Creator)

title: Damita Jo
label: Virgin

title: Antidotes 1 EP
label: self-released

title: Ancestral Recall

label: Warner Bros.

title: When the Pawn...

title: Dreaming the Dark

title: DJ-Kicks

label: Columbia

title: If I Could Only Remember My Name

description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit David Crosby’s solo debut, a foggy dream of psychedelic folk-rock.
