title: Crushing
label: Polyvinyl
description: On an album that mines failed relationships for self-discovery, the Australian singer-songwriter shows her talent at distilling complex situations into searing couplets.

title: Second Language
label: BANA
description: The second album from the experimental Korean rap/production duo really starts to come together. They find a catchy, powerful zone to serve up their invective.

title: Drip or Drown 2
label: Young Stoner Life
description: The drowsy Atlanta rapper polishes his style and submits some of his best songs, but the same thing that makes Gunna dependable also makes him predictable.

title: Father of 4
label: Quality Control
description: Though it’s undermined by its inertia and lack of focus, Offset’s solo debut offers glimpses of the rapper as a compelling storyteller and bluesman.

title: Helium
label: Sinderlyn
description: The former Mac DeMarco guitarist shifts to tepid synths and limp beats on his fourth album, a pastiche of references beyond his reach.

title: Sunshine 3
label: Clone
description: Using a bespoke tuning system, the Finish producer builds his songs inside an otherworldly ecosystem of sound using the pulse of electro, funk, and classic IDM. It is simply alluring.

title: While We Wait
label: TSNMI
description: The Oakland R&B singer’s latest project is a shining example of both her emotional intelligence and her balmy, lucid songwriting.

title: Fabric Presents Bonobo
label: Fabric
description: In the first installment of the London nightclub’s relaunched mix series, an artist best known for soulful, worldly downtempo tries his hand at upbeat house.

title: Lung Bread for Daddy
label: Moshi Moshi
description: Beth Jeans Houghton’s second album as Du Blonde sorts through the messiest aspects of desire and revulsion with cathartic finesse, purging her past while leaving her strange, spiky magic intact.

title: 808BB EP
label: Ilian Tape
description: Following last year’s thrilling Compro, the Ilian Tape label’s breakbeat-techno renegade returns with a three-track EP of club cuts that cleverly flip dancefloor expectations.

title: Silences
label: Canvasback
description: Even if the second album from this Nashville singer doesn’t sound like the blues, she embodies the spirit, squaring up to her demons without fear.

title: Los Angeles
label: Fat Possum
description: A powerful, iconic document of West Coast punk is reissued, warts and all.

title: MTV Unplugged in New York
label: DGC
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Nirvana’s transcendent live acoustic album recorded in 1993.

title: Modern Sounds in Country & Western Music Volumes 1 & 2
label: The Ray Charles Foundation
description: At last available digitally, these quietly revolutionary albums still break one of music’s deepest-held genre orthodoxies.

title: Secrets of the Beehive / Brilliant Trees / Alchemy: An Index of Possibilities / Gone to Earth
label: UMC
description: After the breakup of Japan, this reluctant star retreated into a series of four albums—including his masterpiece—built on noir balladry, instrumental abstraction, and an abiding sense of distance.

title: You Will Not Die
label: BMG
description: The strikingly intimate debut from the London-via-South Africa singer showcases an exciting new talent despite its occasionally lead-footed pacing and stilted theatrics.

title: Serpent Power
label: True Aether
description: Completing the move from hard club music to phantom ambient music, the producer escapes pixel-pocked logic for something more like nature.

title: Illegal Moves
label: Trouble in Mind
description: Calling back to the insurgent sociopolitical jazz from another era of national unrest, these ecstatic instrumentals are urgent and purposeful.

title: Post Earth
label: Wichita
description: The LA quartet’s second album is more musically focused and emotionally unsettled, its once shaggy sound sculpted into post-punk precision.

title: Love Is Love
label: TSO
description: On her second full-length album, the Baltimore rapper indulges in the time-honored queer tradition of plotting a great escape from it all.

title: Steals
label: Other People
description: On his second album for Nicolas Jaar’s label, the Russian producer continues to move away from footwork, building a gloomy world that is strangely welcoming.

title: Mazy Fly
label: Sacred Bones
description: Tia Cabral’s second album retains the great mysticism of her songwriting. The unsettling synth textures and soundscapes fly around her soulful voice, making something beautiful out of sheer terror.

title: Kankyō Ongaku: Japanese Ambient, Environmental & New Age Music 1980-1990
label: Light in the Attic
description: Visible Cloaks’ Spencer Doran curates an appealingly cohesive compilation of Japanese ambient music that, while decades old, feels uncannily suited to contemporary listening habits.

title: Freewave 3
label: self-released
description: The latest project from the 22-year-old Chicago rapper is dour and affecting, a dispatch from a young man able to diagnose his wounds but unable to repair them.

title: Mujeres
label: Tender Loving Empire
description: During this whirlwind of dream pop, folk, and jubilant dance music rendered in Spanish and English, Luz Elena Mendoza steps forward as a singer and bandleader like never before.

title: ALL
label: Mute
description: Best known for his music’s starring role in films like Amélie, the composer aims to become the auteur here—maybe a little too much.

title: Volume One: Dilemmas of Identity
label: Lower Floor
description: On his first solo LP in six years, the noise architect lingers inside a series of haunted scenes, animated by the surreal sounds of homemade instruments.

title: New Atlantis
label: Ostgut Ton
description: Berlin’s Phillip Sollmann strikes a balance between dancefloor techno and avant-garde experiments; his tracks slip into the cracks between common melody and rhythm.

title: Hello Happiness
label: A Diary
description: Co-produced by UK dance mainstay Switch, this comeback album largely ignores all the qualities that made the Queen of Funk a legend in the first place.

title: Crush on Me
label: Father/Daughter
description: Kelsie Hogue’s debut album is likely to be among the year’s most extra albums, but behind its excitable homage to Britney and “TRL” lies an even more intriguing spin on ’90s alternative.

title: Head Above Water
label: BMG
description: Though an interesting showcase of her powerful and newfound voice, the Canadian pop star’s comeback too often lapses into the rote, the stale, or the uninspired.

title: An Attempt to Draw Aside the Veil
label: Sacred Bones
description: On their first album in seven years, the experimental guitarist and lutist craft surprisingly accessible and candid instrumentals from esoteric topics.

title: Cherushii & Maria Minerva
label: 100% Silk
description: Chelsea Faith Dolan perished in Oakland’s Ghost Ship fire in 2016; this EP of left-field dance music made with her 100% Silk labelmate Maria Minerva is a moving testament to her talents and legacy.

title: Another Kind of Revolution
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On her Thrill Jockey debut, this Basque multi-instrumentalist ties together political and personal revolutions with atmospheric and even cinematic ballads.

title: TNT
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the wondrous alchemy of performance and technology found on Tortoise’s third record.

title: Powder in Space
label: Beats in Space
description: On her first official mix album, the Tokyo DJ unveils an intricate, inspired playing style whose value system differs from the typical dancefloor mix.

title: Elder Mantis
label: Leaving
description: On the sort of record that would have once sparked a minor bidding war between Stones Throw and Ninja Tune, hip-hop, IDM, and ambient music drift into a waking dream.

title: The Language of Injury
label: Holy Roar
description: The debut from the UK melodic hardcore band shows their passion for experimentation in a genre where that is desperately welcome.

title: Cast
label: Sub Pop
description: Leaving behind the singer-songwriterly stylings of his previous project, Coldair, Tobiasz Biliński taps the pristine sonics of 1980s sophisti-pop, but it’s often too bloodless for its own good.

title: Solitude
label: Cosmo Rhythmatic
description: Now a duo, Kevin Martin and Roger Robinson strip away all the excess and most of the reggae, yielding a desolate snapshot of heartbreak framed in stark, largely beatless drones.

title: Ladytron
label: !K7
description: A dystopian band for dystopian times, Ladytron return with an angry, pitiless, evil-sounding record whose nihilism presents them as sirens of the apocalypse.

title: In a Galaxy
label: PIAS
description: On her second album, the Dutch-Zimbabwean musician feeds off the energy of a move from Amsterdam to Peckham, England, turning the minutiae of daily life into bold, 1980s-inspired synth pop.

title: Let’s Try the After Vol. 1 EP
label: Arts & Crafts
description: A pleasant palate-cleanser after the nourishing Hug of Thunder, the Canadian collective’s latest EP tackles familiar modes in capable fashion, while offering moments of life-affirming beauty.

title: Rosa Parks: Pure Love. An Oratorio of Seven Songs
label: TUM Records
description: The jazz trumpeter’s meditation on the legacy of civil rights and the heroism of Rosa Parks is formally inventive and emotionally gripping.

title: After its own death / Walking in a spiral towards the house
label: Yellowelectric
description: The new project from Grouper’s Liz Harris contains some of her most beguiling work. Spread across two long, contrasting ambient compositions, her music remains in an enigmatic class of her own.

title: Fyah
label: Gearbox
description: A player in Shabaka Hutchings’ Sons of Kemet and a key figure in London’s vital jazz scene, Cross brings new energy to the tuba, an instrument long neglected in jazz and hits offshoots.

title: Living Tomb
label: 20 Buck Spin
description: On their debut album, this Portland quartet demonstrates their old school death metal bona fides, even when they’re more interested in evolution and atmosphere.

title: Bad Influence
label: Roc Nation
description: A producer with a knack for matching any rapper’s flow and a rapper at his best when embracing his regional flair are, turns out, good influences.

title: Zandoli EP
label: DEEWEE
description: The Belgian-Caribbean musician’s breakout EP, co-produced by Soulwax, channels Guadeloupean influences into striking, playful electro pop with a sly sense of humor.

title: Girl With Basket of Fruit
label: Polyvinyl
description: The duo’s latest speeds between fragmented beats and mournful balladry but rarely makes an impression beyond its sound and fury.

label: Jet Life
description: The ostensible sequel to How Fly offers a few fleeting glimpses of the easygoing, unruffled, and effortlessly cool rap produced by the duo 10 years ago.

title: Main Pop Girl 2019
label: self-released
description: The wonderful second album from James Brooks’ project uses breakbeats, samples, and beautiful rave-pop motifs to tell stories about the bruising power of memory.

title: Empire EP
label: Shelter Press
description: Following last year’s mesmerizing Stadium, this three-track EP is as spacious and richly textured as experimental percussion gets.

title: What It Is
label: Dualtone
description: After a solemn post-divorce album, the Nashville-via-Texas songwriter works his endearing wit back into songs about loving someone new and abhorring social trends.

title: Buoys
label: Domino
description: Noah Lennox finds solace in solitude on his sixth solo album as Panda Bear, stripping the instrumentation down to just a handful of sounds to create an unusually unified listen.

title: Gangway for Navy
label: self-released
description: Built on loud, low-bit-rate samples, the New York rapper uses a relaxed, almost deadpan flow to nestle deep in his own consciousness, drawing you in close to his words.

title: thank u, next
label: Republic
description: Released five months after the catharsis of Sweetener, these songs of affirmation feel lighter, freer, and more fun, carried effortlessly by Grande’s undeniable voice.

title: VOL. 4 :: SLAVES OF FEAR
label: Loma Vista
description: The Los Angeles band used to make lithe, multifaceted songs that wrapped daring pop melodies in bristling noise; now, they seem content to complain into a murky hybrid of trip-hop and metal.

title: AJ Tracey
label: self-released
description: The debut from grime’s rising star is a mixed bag but still peppered with hits, inviting elements of dancehall, pop, trap, and garage to the same house party.

title: A Different Forest
label: Sony Classical
description: With more straightforward performances and compositions, the album has its flat spots, but it hints that Bertelmann might have as much to say as his piano does.

title: A Prince Among Thieves
label: Tommy Boy
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit an ambitious, righteous piece of hip-hop storytelling from 1999.

title: Olympic Girls
label: Ba Da Bing!
description: After an extended search for inspiration, the New Zealand singer/songwriter uses color and newly adventurous song structures to explore definitions and limits of freedom.

title: Tip of the Sphere
label: Anti-
description: On his ninth album, the reserved bandleader incorporates more classic rock references than usual, but they’re the frames for subtleties and surprises within.

title: Severance
label: Central Processing Unit
description: On their second album, the Irish duo Mikron—brothers Michael and Ciaran Corcoran—make promising strides toward defining their own patch of techno turf.

title: Unseen Worlds
label: Unseen Worlds
description: Reissued at last by the label that borrows its name, the second album from the computer music innovator is less predictable, with dark moods rising to a captivating surface.

title: Quiet Signs
label: Mexican Summer
description: The Los Angeles folk musician’s third album is her best yet—a collection of hushed reveries that unspool like daydreams.

title: Live in London
label: Anti-
description: Ten years after her last live record, Live in London feels like a valedictory statement.

title: Pursuit of Momentary Happiness
label: Third Man
description: On their second album, this unruly British trio make the rare garage rock-informed record that aims for the upper reaches of Royal Albert Hall.

title: Bobbie Gentry’s The Delta Sweete Revisited
label: Bella Union
description: A half-century after the release of Bobbie Gentry’s imaginative second album, the art-rock band revisits it as if in a daze but with the help of over a dozen brilliant singers.

title: Oh Boy
label: Female Fantasy
description: In 2010, no band seemed to be having more fun with scrappy garage rock than this one. On their first album in nine years, they forget to replace that spark with anything else.

title: The Oracle
label: International Anthem
description: The debut from the Chicago-based composer and clarinetist serves as a vibrant, spiritual, free-jazz document of black life as it stands today.

title: True North
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: On his second album produced by Steve Gunn, the underground folk icon sings about age and regret with authority and grace.

title: Astronoid
label: Blood
description: On their second album, these metallurgists again find an awesome intersection of black metal pummel and shoegaze luster—then remain there, in its thrall.

title: Electric Lady Sessions
label: Columbia
description: The version of the band that toured behind 2017’s American Dream gathers in the legendary New York studio, giving old songs new life and additional oomph.

title: Big Dreez
label: Interscope
description: After a quiet few years following her 2016 debut, the Chicago rapper returns sounding self-assured, wrapping her sharp flow in lush yet punchy beats.

title: Sunshine Rock
label: Merge
description: After a stretch of dark, searching records, the former Hüsker Dü and Sugar leader uses the familiar power trio configuration to find a little peace.

title: Drift Code
label: Domino
description: Former Talk Talk bassist Paul Webb finally steps to the microphone on his first album in 16 years, a meticulously arranged wonder steeped in English folk and proggy vibes.

title: Music Inspired by the Film Roma
label: Sony
description: The curious, sometimes effective, sometimes bizarre music collected here features contributions from Beck, El-P, Patti Smith, DJ Shadow, Billie Eilish, and more.

title: Emergency Raps Vol. 4
label: Mutant Academy
description: When emcee Fly Anakin and producer Tuamie connect inside a sound infatuated with the hip-hop of the past, it becomes a launch pad to new life.

title: DJ-Kicks
label: !K7
description: The British house producer’s contribution to the longstanding series offers a broad cross-section of his tastes, mostly letting his selections, and not his mixing, do the heavy lifting.

title: Stuffed & Ready
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Leading her thorny rock trio, Clementine Creevy keeps her themes broad and her anger specific as she reflects this moment’s feelings and fatigue.

title: Pure Imagination, No Country
label: Yeggs
description: With a group behind him that recalls the electronic jazz splatter of ’90s New York, Dave Harrington’s guitar work becomes a psychedelic, soft-hued quest for transcendence.

title: Gallipoli
label: 4AD
description: Zach Condon reunites with his old Farfisa on his fifth album, but otherwise he remains cozily ensconced in his twee wheelhouse.

title: On the Other Ocean
label: Lovely
description: Over 40 years after its initial release, the composer’s pioneering work pairing computers with live players feels not only prescient but also refreshingly optimistic.

title: Careful
label: Nude Club
description: A decade after minimal wave seemed to reach its peak, the Massachusetts duo proves the style’s continued vitality.

title: This Is Not the End
label: By The Time It Gets Dark
description: On their debut LP, the Norwegian trio emboldens their customary celebration rock by adding emphatic stretches of post-rock and power-pop.

title: Journey in Satchidananda
label: ABC
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a marvel of spiritual jazz, an album overflowing with transcendence, harmony, and grief.

title: Internationally Unknown
label: Hellcat
description: The fashionable UK punk-rap frontman has been made into an icon, but his second album is too often a pale and rote imitation of rebellion.

title: Michael O’Shea
label: Allchival
description: Originally released on the UK post-punk group Wire’s label in 1982, this long-lost one-off spotlights a singular busker who made magical music out of a stringed wooden door.

title: Tatizo Pesa
label: Nyege Nyege Tapes
description: Jay Mitta adds an incredible amount of detail to the frenetic and kinetic sound of singeli, a blisteringly quick style of dance music from Dar Es Salaam, Tanzania.

title: Mystery Hour
label: Bella Union
description: This baroque pop record is pleasant and roomy, but peer inside to find a fragmented portrait of heartbreak shared by the band’s cofounders.

title: Comp x Comp
label: Comatonse
description: As the Tokyo experimental musician’s work is finally made available digitally, this compilation offers an introduction to the artist’s critical perspective on capitalism, gender norms, trans identity, and more.

title: Scenery
label: ATO
description: The New York singer-songwriter’s third album maps life’s changes to sleek, vibrant R&B that’s packed with 1980s soundtrack flourishes and big moments; it’s the perfect frame for her extraordinary voice.

title: Hueco Mundo
label: NUXSENSE
description: The solo debut from one of the Dublin rap group NUXSENSE’s core emcees, backed by ghostly beats from producer Sivv, represents the clearest iteration of the group’s aesthetic yet.

title: What Chaos is Imaginary
label: Anti-
description: Weaving in and out of concrete, direct, indie-rock songwriting and meditative, impressionistic dream pop, Girlpool’s third album features their most expansive and surreal songs to date.

title: Bartier Bounty
label: Asylum
description: Already an all-time-great shit talker, the Detroit rapper reaffirms his reputation as a fun-loving rapper who repurposes familiar topics in new forms.

title: Almost Free
label: Mom & Pop
description: A little Gary Glitter, a little Kid Rock, even a little Smash Mouth—the third album from these former California party kids holds nothing back.

title: Everything’s for Sale
label: Shady
description: The Compton rapper’s debut is smart, technically dazzling, and thoroughly sullen.

title: D A Y S
label: Northern Spy
description: Perhaps familiar from her time in Okkervil River, the multi-instrumentalist builds fascinating webs of sound around skeletal songs on her solo debut.

title: Isa
label: Posh Isolation
description: The sixth album from Loke Rahbek’s experimental industrial project is his most cohesive to date, dissecting pop for parts and refiguring melodic elements into something truly other.

title: Signals Into Space
label: Les Disques du Crépuscule
description: After 30 years, the London duo sounds more refined than ever, though their mix of ethereal jazz, ambient electronics, and mechanized drums has rarely been harder to define.

title: Epitaph
label: Bokeh Versions
description: On what is billed as his proper debut LP after several years’ worth of cassette releases, the Greek producer fashions a wide-ranging attempt to move beyond his dub influences.

title: Goes West
label: Merge
description: The solo guitarist’s fourth album is soft and subtle, approaching the strains of pop while still basking in the solitude of Americana.

title: Nectar
label: YEAR0001
description: The lo-fi, art rock project from Yung Lean is every bit as dazed as his rap music, while otherwise sounding almost nothing like it.

title: La Maison de la Mort/Minimal Cuts EP
label: Berceuse Heroique
description: The Russian producer better known as Buttechno applies his gonzo sonics to psychoactive ambient miniatures and joyfully off-kilter club tracks.

title: Nighttime Birds and Morning Stars
label: Thrill Jockey
description: After first gaining attention for representational acoustic beauties, the guitarist digs deeper into abstraction, until the physical trappings of her instrument largely melt away.

title: All the Young Droogs
label: Cherry Red
description: Subtitled ”60 Juvenile Delinquent Wrecks, Rock’N’Glam (And a Flavour of Bubblegum) From the ’70s,” this collection makes a fine argument for glam as punk-before-punk and speaks to the herd mentality of rock‘s heyday.

title: La Onda de Juan Pablo
label: Captured Tracks
description: On his first album sung entirely in Spanish, the Uruguayan-American singer-songwriter finds poetry in small moments, with low-key craftsmanship that matches his songs’ quotidian subject matter.

title: King of the Dudes EP
label: Mom & Pop
description: Though still a bit shaky and cloying, the New York band strikes a good chord with a power-pop sound and starts to carve out a space of their own.

title: new breed
label: Local Action
description: Moving in a more traditional R&B direction, new breed is a richly detailed, self-confident, yet somewhat uneven album that attempts to weave together disparate elements of Richard’s personality.

title: Dry As a Bone/Rehab Doll
label: Sub Pop
description: Now reissued in expanded editions, the first official Sub Pop release—and its full-length follow-up—deserve more than historical footnote status.

title: Highway Hypnosis
label: Merge
description: On her third album, the magnetic D.C. multi-instrumentalist pushes from post-punk toward a new clutch of electronic influences, seemingly sorting them as she goes.

title: Private Parts
label: Lovely
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a surreal, transcendental work by a giant of the American avant-garde.

title: We All Shine
label: self-released
description: A true child of SoundCloud, the small-town Florida rapper trades some of his storytelling skills for enhanced fidelity on this Kanye West-assisted project.

title: Black Axis/The Tribe
label: Southern Lord
description: The start of an extended reissues series, these two albums find the essential trio of the aggressive German guitarist fighting through darkness to find any light.

title: Better Oblivion Community Center
label: Dead Oceans
description: Phoebe Bridgers and Conor Oberst team up for a tight-knit folk-rock album about alienation, solitude, and our potential to better ourselves against bad odds.

title: The Unseen in Between
label: Matador
description: Though he rose to early acclaim as a fingerstyle guitarist, the singer/songwriter is steadily developing into a poignant lyricist, now chronicling the places and people he hopes to understand.

title: Oliver Appropriate
label: Dine Alone
description: In what is billed as the emo band’s farewell album, Max Bemis concocts a tangled rock opera about a burnt-out singer grappling with his rage and his sexuality.

title: In the Living Room
label: Seal Mountain
description: Crisp and shiny as a compact disc, these 10 songs position the North Carolina upstarts as late-1990s alt-connoisseurs, unashamed of and unapologetic about their enthusiasms.

title: Power Chords
label: Merge
description: Pledging allegiance to fuzz, this power-pop barrage squares off against heartache, disappointment, and sleepless nights—and survives.

title: Future Hndrxx Presents: The WIZRD
label: Epic
description: While there’s plenty of his melancholic, drug-induced staples, what you won’t find here is the Atlanta rapper stretching or surprising himself.

title: Musical Prophet: The Expanded 1963 New York Studio Sessions
label: Resonance
description: Made months before he cut his masterpiece and almost exactly a year before he died, these newly excavated recordings show the exploratory vigor and versatility of the jazz revolutionary.

title: direct line to My Creator
label: The Vanguarde Craft and Creative
description: The remarkable EP from the New York-based artist is a one-of-a-kind debut, filled with small details, warm soul, and great emotional depth.

title: Tomb
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: The Los Angeles singer-songwriter’s third album, his most polished to date, covers the full spectrum of brokenheartedness.

title: Rat’s Spit
label: Underwater Peoples
description: On his first album since joining Real Estate, the hesitant singer and lavish sound artist at last puts those elements on equal footing with his songwriting.

title: Phoenix
label: Polyvinyl
description: Assuming his old handle for the first time in 15 years, David Bazan digs into his desert childhood to make amends with the people he hurt—especially himself.

title: Outer Peace
label: Carpark
description: Chaz Bear delivers a smartly crafted, comfortably mid-fi album of grooves and melancholy—one of his best albums in years.

title: Assume Form
label: Polydor
description: There’s a suffocating seriousness that runs through the singer and producer’s fourth album, one that bogs down genuine moments of levity and love.

title: Heard It in a Past Life
label: Capitol
description: Three years after an encounter with Pharrell turned her into a viral phenomenon, the accidental star finally delivers her debut album, but her talents are eclipsed by overproduction.

title: The Favourite (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Decca
description: A dizzying mix of Baroque, religious, mid-century, and contemporary classical music, this soundtrack captures its film’s tempestuous relationship with power and feelings.

title: Love Hates What You Become
label: Mute
description: On their second album, Ebony Hoorn and WU LYF’s Ellery Roberts sell a mix of motivation and despair with sheer bombast.

title: Tracy Chapman
label: Elektra
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a folk classic that came to the world stage with a perspective crystallized in society’s margins.

title: The Sensual World
label: EMI
description: Never did Kate Bush sound more grounded, more in control of her songwriting than on her sixth album from 1989, featuring stories that play out like intimate vignettes rather than fantastical fairy tales.

title: The Dreaming
label: EMI
description: In 1982, Kate Bush’s daring and dense fourth album marked her transformation into a fearless experimental artist who was legibly, audibly very queer, and very obviously in love with pop music.

title: The Red Shoes
label: EMI
description: An outlier in Kate Bush’s catalog, her seventh album from 1993 finds an effortless perfectionist pushing very hard to locate her next great idea.

title: The Kick Inside
label: EMI
description: Released when she was just 19, and including songs begun four years earlier, Bush’s landmark debut is playful, experimental, and defiant: the sound of a young woman getting what she wants.

title: Hectic Shakes EP
label: Alter
description: The German producer tests the balance of bleak ambience and diamond-tipped breakbeats on an introspective EP that remains true to his own idiosyncratic style.

title: Nūr EP
label: AGAINST GIANTS
description: The debut EP from the Sudan-born, Twin Cities-based singer, poet, and activist reveals an artist with a warm, sophisticated sound and captivating presence on the mic.

title: Remind Me Tomorrow
label: ‎Jagjaguwar‎
description: On her fifth album, Sharon Van Etten conjures tempests and explores their subsequent calms. It is the peak of her songwriting and her most atmospheric, emotionally piercing album to date.

title: Scholars
label: Brassland
description: On their first album in six years, the experimental pop duo (mostly) puts down their namesake instruments to fold more electronic elements into their potent songs.

title: About the Light
label: Double Six
description: The infamous Beta Band frontman could have lingered in the shadow of his cult-figure fandom; instead, on his fourth solo album, he sings directly about the long process of growing up.

title: Why Hasn’t Everything Already Disappeared?
label: 4AD
description: Though the band is now squarely in its pop era, the nostalgia that laced its early records has morphed into a timely, fatalistic vision of the future and national decay.

title: Malibu Ken
label: Rhymesayers
description: Teaming with the playful producer Tobacco, Aesop Rock has a joyous playdate with his overlooked senses of humor and storytelling.

title: 13th Month
label: Apocalipsis
description: The Dominican producer pulls inspiration from a South Dakota Indian Reservation.

title: Bird Box (Abridged) Original Score
label: The Null Corporation
description: The soundtrack institution of Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross return to their well of ominousness and employ an array of techniques to convey anxiety, impending danger, and discomfort.

title: Untitled II
label: a-ton
description: On their second major outing for a label other than their own, the eternally enigmatic producer uses frantic EBM and lurid synths to cast a shadow as dark and deep as their reputation.

title: Prehysteria
label: Boogie Agency
description: The New York band’s jangly indie pop is more ambitious than before, but their lyrics too often fail to move beyond low-stakes camp—hardly the radical liberation the band has hinted at delivering.

title: AMITY
label: Baby Gang
description: The California-based producer, instrumental to the rise of emo-rap, offers a solid showcase of his talent that maps a constellation of strange and unforgettable artists.

title: Tides: Music for Meditation and Yoga
label: touchtheplants
description: Music for yoga may be an ambient cliche, but the Los Angeles synthesizer musician largely avoids new-age pitfalls on this album of unabashedly functional background music.

title: Spirit of Eden
label: Parlophone
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the masterful, groundbreaking sound that laid the foundation for post-rock.

title: DISRUPTION EP
label: Club Chai
description: The Bay Area producer’s debut project draws upon Armenian mythology to create an ambient-house-dabke hybrid in five shape-shifting tracks.

title: first bloom
label: self-released
description: On spirited songs that shift eagerly among pop, hip-hop, rock, and soul, the voice of standout singer Wolf Weston emerges as a stirring new instrument.

title: “…The Best Live Show of All Time” — NME EP
label: Nonesuch
description: Even given the tongue-in-cheek hyperbole of the title, this six-track live EP fails to live up the former Talking Heads frontman’s former heights.

title: Lost Lovesongs / Lostsongs Vol. 2
label: Planet Uterus
description: On a pair of 30-minute SoundCloud streams, the former Giegling affiliate applies his windswept aesthetic to boom-bap, ambient, and jungle, to emotive—some would say maudlin—effect.

title: Transportation EPs
label: Telephone Explosion
description: Perhaps familiar from being sampled by the Avalanches, this New York tween was an inspiring underground star in the early 1980s, a reputation confirmed by this archival collection.

title: Roman Birds
label: self-released
description: Inspired by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius, this five-track ambient wonder finds the New York producer letting pulses and motifs overlap until the tracks resemble the inside of a lava lamp.

title: Shadows of Death and Desire
label: Hospital Productions
description: On his second solo album, fueled by unspecified personal misfortune, the former Sandwell District member finds emotional resonance in the interface between techno and post-punk.

title: Sick Boy
label: Disruptor
description: Trading away the dance-pop trifles of their hits for a faceless stylistic shuffle, the duo seems to be tiring of itself, too.

title: Hoodie SZN
label: Atlantic
description: Despite the typical bloated-album problems like pacing issues and forced collaborations, A Boogie hardly ever loses his Bronx edge.

title: V I S C 0 9
label: V I S
description: On a tape label with links to Hamburg’s Golden Pudel club, the German curator delivers a deep-diving, pitch-shifting DJ mix traversing Alice Coltrane, desert blues, and cacophonous synths and drums.

title: Ménage à Trois: Sextape Vol. 1, 2, 3
label: Radiokilla
description: Totalling a bulky 40 songs, Terius Nash’s latest project is purposefully and hilariously indulgent, but his marathon session reveals an R&B luminary still working at the top of his game.

title: Starter Home
label: No Quarter
description: Gracefully navigating the intersection of folk-rock and country, the gentle-voiced songwriter turns detailed images of domestic tranquility and promise into reflections on disappointment.

title: Singles Going Steady
label: IRS
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a punk classic, a paragon of songwriting about the pain and joy of love.

title: Happy New Year! We Wish You Happiness!
label: трип
description: The latest compilation from Nina Kraviz’s label explores the fringes of techno with a twisted grin.

title: Nothing New in the West
label: self-released
description: The debut from the prodigious singer-songwriter is a fussy and affecting album of baroque art-rock that is crowded with ideas in the best way.

title: War in My Pen
label: 10k
description: Of MIKE’s four projects last year, War in My Pen is the cleanest-sounding, but the New York rapper still prizes a faraway vibe that rewards close listening.

title: Universalis
label: Hammock
description: This long-running Nashville duo captures the essence of their name with a low-slung, low-stakes sway, tracing a line between languid indie rock and experimental atmospheres.

title: X 100PRE
label: Rimas
description: The expertly sequenced and always vibrant debut from the Puerto Rican rapper collects every fascinating side of Bad Bunny into one singular statement.

title: Take 2 EP
label: Because Music
description: Though an accomplished actress, the French star fails to sell her cover of Kanye West’s “Runaway” on an EP that otherwise amounts to a deserved victory lap.

title: I Am > I Was
label: Slaughter Gang
description: The second album from one of Atlanta’s most promising rappers recasts him as a star in waiting. He writes with grisly clarity and humor, and his songs here are sturdy, inventive, and sticky.

title: Signs of Satanic Youth
label: Emergency
description: These Australians became radio mainstays at home after missing the grunge gold rush, but their debut EP remains a potent encapsulation of alternative rock in the early 1990s.

title: Some Kind of Cadwallader
label: Lauren
description: The Pennsylvania emo stalwarts never found much fame in their own time, but a decade later, these reissues testify to their influence, idiosyncrasy, and proudly uncommercial spirit.

title: A Day In The Life: Impressions Of Pepper
label: Verve
description: This version of Sgt Pepper’s treats the Beatles' originals like colorful clothes worn by today’s most electrifying jazz musicians, who give these old chestnuts a new body and vitality.

title: Language
label: BANA
description: The debut from the young hip-hop duo is an antidote to mainstream South Korean rap and pop—personal, anti-capitalist screeds over experimental trap and techno hybrids.

title: Foxwarren
label: Anti-
description: Songwriter Andy Shauf puts his solo success on hold for an atmospheric rock record with his friends—appropriate for these tunes about seeking solace in a lonely world.

title: Opening Fire: 2008-2014
label: Dark Operative
description: This collection of early recordings from the Texas thrash powerhouse makes it clear that their influences and focus set them apart from the thrash revival they followed.

title: Alienated
label: Sister Polygon
description: On their first release for the D.C. punk band Priests’ label, the duo finally let a little light into their rough-and-tumble rock songs, celebrating in spite of hardships.

title: Vox Lux OST
label: Columbia
description: If a soundtrack to a troubled movie that features half Sia songs and half Scott Walker compositions sounds at the very least interesting, rest assured, it is not.

title: Temporary etc.
label: NNA Tapes
description: One of several recent drummers to combine electronic processing with instrumental chops, Booker Stardrum swings like a pendulum between chaos and order.

title: Distancing
label: Buzz
description: The songwriting from Laura Hermiston on her latest indie-pop album is noisy but lucid, reflective of the sound and vision coming from Toronto’s Buzz Records.

title: Lost Time Behind the Moon
label: Scissor Tail
description: After decades of wandering, the former Court & Spark and Hiss Golden Messenger member follows his wanderlust West again, where he puts down new roots for his soulful folk-rock sound.

title: Chronicles II / Chronicles III
label: a-ton
description: At one point, Luke Slater’s atmospheric-techno guise sounded like the future of electronic music; a welcome new archive proves its soundscapes and grooves were prescient.

title: Icarus Falls
label: RCA
description: Zayn’s reputation as a skillful interpreter of pop is tested on his second solo album, a tome of love songs with a concept that hinges on excess and its trickery.

title: Penelope Two
label: Houndstooth
description: Summoning the great ghosts of vintage 4AD and Kranky, the Australian singer and producer makes inky dream pop that’s as heavy and welcoming as a weighted blanket.

title: Sistahs
label: Daydream Library Series
description: The accomplished debut from the DIY UK post-punk trio is simmering with possibility and pure conviction.

title: Trust Issues
label: SOB X RBE
description: SOB X RBE is already a compelling rap machine, a potential powerhouse in waiting. But this solo outing suggests that there’s plenty of life outside the group, too.

title: Let Go
label: Arista
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a teenage fever dream, the mainstream pop-punk debut of Avril Lavigne.

title: The Capitol Studio Sessions
artist: Jeff Goldblum & The Mildred Snitzer Orchestra
label: Decca
description: Jeff Goldblum’s debut album, a live-in-the-studio ersatz nightclub affair, is a sincere, classy, and competent homage to the golden age of vocal jazz.

title: Stokeley
label: Victor Victor
description: On his album debut, the South Florida rapper (and former XXXTentacion associate) employs a playful approach to celebrate style over substance.

title: Skins
label: Bad Vibes Forever
description: Underneath it all, the posthumous album from the Florida rapper is woefully aimless and structurally unsound.

title: A Million and One
label: Rhyme & Reason
description: In pursuit of sweaty deliverance, the acrobatic singer takes worries about police brutality, relationship woes, and embracing differences to the dance floor.

title: Springsteen on Broadway
label: Columbia
description: Even when Bruce sticks to the script in a playhouse, he can deliver a ranging and intimate performance full of the history and emotion befitting his long career.

title: Live in Buenos Aires
label: Parlophone
description: Though it includes some of the band’s least memorable songs, their latest live album makes a strong case for Coldplay as one of the 21st century’s most enduring arena acts.

title: Puff O’Gigio
label: Bad Paintings
description: On their fourth album together, Xiu Xiu and Larsen create a sense of cinematic whimsy anchored around a mythological creature who helps with household chores.

title: The Chic Organization 1977-1979
label: Rhino
description: The latest in a long line of box sets and anthologies collects the pioneering disco duo’s core albums. Despite the songs’ deep familiarity, they still represent pop at its most triumphant and complex.

title: MONOAkuma
label: Room40
description: Meant as an introduction to 40 years of a prolific noise icon, this live recording moves between grating analog and prickling digital modes with unmitigated force.

title: DiCaprio 2
label: Dreamville
description: The East Atlanta rapper’s second album doesn't try to take on the world and is all the better for it, showing that J.I.D. has much more to offer than his formidable rapping chops.

title: Evil Genius
label: Atlantic
description: Though it’s one of his most considered and carefully curated projects, Gucci plays it uncharacteristically safe for most of it.

title: Sky Lake
label: Tiny Engines
description: Fleshing out its classic indie-rock sound with synths, Auto-Tune, and other hazy production touches, the North Carolina duo searches for dream-pop atmospheres in the muggy Florida landscape.

title: Send Flowers
label: Sophomore Lounge
description: The Midwestern band’s fourth album cleans up their “punked-up country gunk,” giving more space to Ryan Davis’ incisive, deceptively offhand lyrics.

title: Your Dog
label: Father/Daughter
description: After years of recording and quietly releasing beatific folk music, the Bay Area singer/songwriter flexes her voice and vision on pop songs of complicated feelings and private anxieties.

title: Look
label: New Deal
description: The rising producer has made records with John Legend and Perfume Genius. On his new instrumental record, he expresses exquisite vulnerability at the intersection of ambient and modern classical.

title: Manos
label: Merge
description: One of the first non-grunge bands on Sub Pop showed just how malleable underground pop could be; a quarter-century later, their debut remains a bracing, brazen showcase of rock minimalism.

title: Paranoid
label: Vertigo
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the dawn of metal, a document of dreary working-class blight and anti-war screeds.

title: EP ONE
label: Nomad
description: On her debut EP, the Kazakh/British violinist, likely most familiar from work with Radiohead, creates teeming and imagistic environments with four strings and electronics.

title: Hence
label: Editions Mego
description: On their third duo album, the two longtime accomplices balance free-improv flux with compositional rigor in a suite-like piece for guitar, electronics, and tabla.

title: Pop Ambient 2019
label: Kompakt
description: Kompakt co-founder Wolfgang Voigt curates the latest in the label’s ambient series with a compilation of dark and moody tracks that reflect the best of what modern-day ambient has to offer.

title: Throne
label: Editions Mego
description: Known for her improvisational aplomb, the pedal steel guitarist and singer returns with her second and most complex batch of composed songs, subversive and rich documents of love and lust.

title: Utopia Teased
label: Western Vinyl
description: Recorded in the wake of the Ghost Ship fire and in a haze of psychedelics, these luminous pop songs articulate grief as a means of moving past it.

title: The Pains of Growing
label: Def Jam
description: The pop singer hits a soft reset on her second album, which isn’t a revelation, but it has the tinge of a project made with love and devotion.

title: Brace Up!
label: Palilalia
description: On their studio debut, these frenzied improvisers tap the ecstasy and explosiveness of their onstage chemistry while capturing their ideas and enthusiasms in vivid, glorious detail.

title: Young HeartThrob
label: Epic
description: On her debut LP, the young Atlanta rapper and singer avoids guests and try-hard hits while embracing a voice that runs like water.

title: Heavy Down Pour EP
label: Misery Club
description: The latest project from the alt-rap Misery Club member showcases his dynamic voice and features a grip of collaborators from Clams Casino to Alice Glass that often overshadow Zubin’s personality.

title: Live at Third Man Records
label: Third Man
description: Recorded in Nashville, the spare set of songs taken from his last three solo albums is a minor but revealing statement from the graceful singer-songwriter.

title: Breakfast
label: Gloriette
description: Borrowing the sample-crazed approach of the Avalanches, this unlikely California trio create winning tunes from a junkyard jumble of soft-rock keys and big breakbeats.

title: Glastonbury 2000
label: Parlophone
description: The workmanlike renditions of hits he hadn’t played in years don’t rank among his best live takes, but there’s still a thrill in revisiting this curious point in the shape-shifting star’s career.

title: From the Dirt
label: Dirt Tech Reck
description: The Detroit producer and Slum Village alum makes house music that’s true to his hometown’s diverse, deeply rooted legacy, with elements of R&B, funk, and soul informing its four-to-the-floor bounce.

title: Merrie Land
artist: The Good, the Bad & the Queen
label: Studio 13
description: On its first album in 11 years, the Damon Albarn-fronted supergroup tackles Brexit head on. In his “Anglo-Saxistentialist” reckoning, false nostalgia imperils a true vision of British identity.

title: IIWII (It Is What It Is)
label: Pro Era
description: The Pro Era rapper finds the middle of the road on his latest project, chasing hot sounds in lieu of finding his own.

title: Diplomatic Ties
label: Set Life
description: Dipset were always a theater of the absurd. On their first album in more than a decade, Cam’ron, Juelz Santana, and Jim Jones become a trio of almost no effort.

title: Championships
label: Maybach Music Group
description: Despite being born of injustice, an air of victory hangs over Meek’s first full-length since he was released from prison. It captures an intensity that the Philadelphia rapper is known for and best at.

title: Iron Maiden / Killers / The Number of the Beast / Piece Of Mind
label: Parlophone
description: Though at least two of Maiden’s first four albums are metal masterpieces, they showcase a band eagerly evolving while building a classic lineup in a breathless four-year span.

title: Spencer Sings the Hits!
label: In the Red
description: For his first album under his own name, the ever-wild guitar renegade lampoons the posers and newbies while again rewiring rock’n’roll until the circuits almost short.

title: Like Memory Foam
label: Damnably
description: On their second record, the Columbus, Ohio quartet play away the pain.

title: DUMMY BOY
label: ScumGang Records
description: There’s nothing redeeming about Tekashi 6ix9ine’s DUMMY BOY, though he surely wishes there was.

title: WARM
label: dBpm
description: On his first ever collection of original solo songs—a companion piece to his recent memoir—the Wilco leader uncovers himself like never before.

title: Homework
label: Virgin
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Daft Punk’s debut, the duo’s greatest illusion yet.

title: Songs for Judy
label: Shakey Pictures
description: Collecting two-dozen highlights from 1976 solo sets, this candid document finds the singer sorting through old standards and almost-lost classics at a particularly restless moment.

title: Tommy Genesis
label: Downtown
description: On her debut album, the playful Canadian rapper is bossed up, horny, or lonely as she searches for a sound to match her shrugged-off swagger.

title: The Bela Session
label: Leaving
description: The original studio version of goth’s transcendent standard finally gets reissued alongside three songs that show just how quickly the band progressed.

title: Ens
label: Thrill Jockey
description: After two astounding EPs last year, half of the droning duo Mountains returns with an intimate, affectionate album inspired by the birth of his child.
